The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

div.head: Extract of a Letter to the Author.
div.p: A GENTLEMAN in this town, to whom Mr. Leaming's "Defence" was lately ≈øent, ≈øaw fit, a few days ago, to put it into my hands, de≈øiring I would give it a reading; which I have accordingly done.

How far it may be ju≈øtly called, a Defence of Epi≈øcopacy again≈øt your ≈øermon, I am not able to ≈øay; not having had „Äà‚óä„Äâ plea≈øure of ever ≈øeeing it: But 'tis with great impropriety ≈øtiled a defence again≈øt mine; as nineteen parts in twenty of what I had ≈øaid, is pa≈ø≈øed over, without ≈øo much as an attempt to examine its force, or ≈øhew its inconclu≈øivene≈øs in point of argument. Was it not that my name is now and then mentioned, no one would imagine he had it in view to an≈øwer me, any more than an hundred others, who have appeared on the ≈øame ≈øide of the que≈øtion in di≈øpute.

I e≈øteem my ≈øermon as full an an≈øwer to his "defence," as if wrote on purpo≈øe to confute it; and a≈øk no other favour than that they be carefully compared with each other, and an impartial judgment formed thereupon. If this is done, I can't ≈øuppo≈øe that any one, be≈øides Mr. L. will be di≈øpo≈øed to think, that he has an≈øwered the mo≈øt material things advanced by Dr. Chauncy: It mu≈øt be determined, on the contrary, that he has ≈øcarce taken notice of any thing material that I have offered.

I have no other knowledge of this gentleman, than what may be collected from this ≈ømall work of his; which has not, I confe≈øs, given me an exalted opinion
of him. Was I inclined to engage-in the epi≈øcopal controver≈øy, I ≈øhould choo≈øe for my opponent, one that is better able to manage a di≈øpute, than he appears to me to be. What good purpo≈øe would it ≈øerve to write, though it were never ≈øo clearly and ≈øtrongly, when one knows before hand, that little notice may be taken of what is wrote, and yet the whole be completely an≈øwered?‚ÄîHe has ≈øaid but little, very little but what has been an≈øwered an hundred times over, and with arguments much too powerful to be ≈øet a≈øide by him.

I am ≈øorry your lot is ca≈øt among tho≈øe who are deeply tinctured with high-church principles. Such are always bigots them≈øelves, and zealou≈øly endeavor to make others ≈øo too. This was the ca≈øe among us in former years; but the≈øe high-flying notions are now almo≈øt ab≈øorbed in a more generous way of thinking. There are but few who dare openly profe≈øs their adherence to the≈øe tenets, whatever their private thoughts may be. 'Tis indeed high time they were univer≈øally eradicated out of men's minds, they are ≈øo ≈øen≈øele≈øs in them≈øelves, as well as contrary to the word of God.
However, as the ca≈øe is circum≈øtanced with you, it may be well for you to take him to ta≈øk, and point out his weakne≈øs; which, as I imagine, you will find no difficult matter.

It would be doing too much honour to him, for us both to be engaged in the di≈øpute with him: Though I believe it is in reality a di≈øpute with the combined clergy in tho≈øe parts. By the account I have of Mr. L. he is not equal to the performance that comes out in his name, however in≈øufficient it may be as an an≈øwer to either of us.

div.head: INTRODUCTION.
div.p:
WHEN I preached and publi≈øhed my di≈øcour≈øe upon ordination, I had no thoughts of engaging in a controver≈øy. Providence had ca≈øt my lot in that part of Chri≈øt's vineyard, where there are ≈øundry epi≈øcopalians, inter≈øper≈øed among the people of my charge, as well as in the neighborhood. Though I never could find any ≈øcripture warrant, for the peculiarities that di≈øtingui≈øh that church from the re≈øt of the prote≈øtant world; tho' it has many defects in its orders, wor≈øhip and di≈øcipline, and is con≈øiderably different from the plan laid down by our Saviour and his apo≈øtles, and followed by the primitive chri≈øtians in the next ≈øucceeding ages; yet as it appears to have the e≈ø≈øentials of religion, it has ever been my practice to treat its profe≈ø≈øors as chri≈øtian brethren, tho' mi≈øtaken in ≈øome points; agreeable to the apo≈øtolic direction, Him that is weak in the faith receive, but not to doubtful di≈øputations. A wrangling di≈øputatious temper among the di≈øciples, e≈øpecially among the mini≈øters of the Prince of Peace, is odious and unchri≈øtian. As the things in which we agree, are, by all allowed, to be of infinitely greater importance than tho≈øe in which we differ; how can that zeal be defended which ≈øpends it≈øelf only, or principally, about the latter, while the former are treated with comparative neglect? Is it not much more becoming the character of chri≈øtians and mini≈øters of the go≈øpel, to lay a≈øide the≈øe bickerings, and unite our endeavours
in oppo≈øing the growing cau≈øe of infidelity and irreligon, and promoting the more important truths of our common chri≈øtianity? The≈øe are the principles agreeable to which I have ever treated our epi≈øcopal di≈ø≈øenters: And I challenge the whole party „Äà‚óä„Äâ produce an in≈øtance, in which I have ever begun a di≈øpute with them upon the controverted points, or attempted, publicly or privately, to prejudice them again≈øt their own wor≈øhip or mini≈øtry. I e≈øteem it a greater honour to promote the real intere≈øt of religion, than that of any particular denomination; and, if I know my own hears, had much rather be the happy in≈øtrument of ≈øavingly converting one ≈øoul to Chri≈øt; than of making a thou≈øand pro≈øelytes, merely to the low de≈øigns of a party. It has ever given me pain, to ob≈øerve the prevalence of a contrary temper and conduct, in tho≈øe of any denomination, whether clergy or laity. How far this has been the ca≈øe with the epi≈øcopalians in the≈øe parts, would, perhaps, be deemed invidious in me to ≈øay. Sure I am, if I had not ob≈øerved too many in≈øtances of this kind; had I not been repeatedly ≈øolicited, to preach and publi≈øh upon the ≈øubject, as a nece≈ø≈øary antidote again≈øt the effects of them; the di≈øcour≈øe I am now called upon to vindicate, never would have ≈øeen the light. In compo≈øing of it, I ≈øtudiou≈øly guarded again≈øt every thing offen≈øive; for I had no de≈øire to be drawn into a controver≈øy. Had I been di≈øpo≈øed to this, I could not have been at a lo≈øs for materials. It is well known, that be≈øides the exorbitant, un≈øcriptural claims of their bi≈øhops, and the mean, ≈øervile ≈øubjection of the pre≈øbyters, in that church; there are ≈øome things in her articles, and in her wor≈øhip and di≈øcipline many more, which are, (at lea≈øt in our opinion) highly exceptionable. However naturally many of the≈øe things fell in my way, while writing upon
this ≈øubject, I carefully ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed them; for my maxim was to act only on the defen≈øive, and endeavour, by ≈øcripture and rea≈øon, to vindicate our mini≈øterial authority from the perpetual attacks of the party. In the≈øe circum≈øtances, I had rea≈øon to conclude, that the mo≈øt ≈øanguine and zealous among them would not be offended, or look upon them≈øelves concerned to an≈øwer me, either from the pulpit or the pre≈øs. But no ≈øooner was the piece publi≈øhed, than the epi≈øcopa pulpits, here and in the neighborhood, re≈øounded with the old cry, "the power, the power;" and repeatedly rung over all the various changes, „Äà‚óä„Äâ the nullity of pre≈øbyterian orders and admini≈øtrations, the ab≈øolute nece≈ø≈øity of uninterrupted ≈øucce≈ø≈øion, and the unalterable and divine right o ‚Ä¢ epi≈øcopacy. And among the re≈øt, it was ≈øaid, Mr. L. often di≈øtingui≈øhed him≈øelf upon the topic, with ≈øingular pathos and zeal.

IT was ≈øoon given out, that an an≈øwer to my piece would be publi≈øhed: But as no particular author was named, and the rumour abated; it was generally concluded, as they had no call to engage in the controver≈øy, the de≈øign was laid a≈øide. However, after a preparation of near three years, Mr. L. has ≈øeen fit to ≈øtep forth, and favor the public with the fir≈øt fruits of his pen, in what he is plea≈øed to call A defence of the epi≈øcopal government of the church, containing remarks upon two late noted ≈øermons, on pre≈øbyterian ordination.

WHAT I was to expect, from ≈øuch an opponent, I was at a lo≈øs to determine; having never had a ta≈øte of his abilities for managing a controver≈øy. When the book came out, I read it with a good degree of attention; and was not a little ≈øurprized to find, that after ≈øo long preparation, the author had ≈øo little to ≈øay, upon the two pieces he had
≈øet him≈øelf to an≈øwer. As to Dr. Chauncy's, the Dr. ju≈øtly ob≈øerves, nineteen parts in twenty are pa≈ø≈øed over without a ≈øingle remark. And as to mine, whoever compares it with Mr. L's an≈øwer, will, I am confident, make much the ≈øame remark. Whether he has ≈øo fully ≈øucceeded, in tho≈øe parts he pretends to an≈øwer, mu≈øt be ≈øubmitted to the judgment of the public, to which I appeal.

FOR the≈øe and ≈øuch like rea≈øons, it was judged at fir≈øt, that to attempt an an≈øwer was no ways nece≈ø≈øary. But as the party ≈øoon began to triumph in it, as an unan≈øwerable piece, and boa≈øted of great exploits done by it, in the addition of ≈øundry converts to the epi≈øcopal cau≈øe; it was generally concluded, that ≈øomething ought to be wrote by way of reply. This, I hoped, would have been undertaken by Dr. Chauncy, as every way my ≈øuperior, e≈øpecially in his acquaintance with this controver≈øy. But as he has declined the ≈øervice, for the rea≈øons mentioned in his letter, prefixed to the≈øe ≈øheets; it of cour≈øe devolves upon me.

As I am con≈øcious of no other motive in the affair, than a ≈øincere regard to truth, and the intere≈øt of our churches, which I really believe to be the intere≈øt of the Redeemer's kingdom; I ≈øhall endeavour fairly to examine every thing in Mr. L's book, that looks like an argument, and give it its due weight. For as it is truth rather than victory I aim at; ≈øo the former will ≈øhine brighte≈øt when placed in contra≈øt with every thing that oppo≈øes it; and as to the latter, he who ≈øhould challenge it for only nibbling at here and there a ≈øentence in his antagoni≈øt, mu≈øt I conceive, appear with a very ill grace. This, however, will make me more lengthy, than might otherwi≈øe be thought needful.

ONE thing I think proper to premi≈øe.‚ÄîSince, notwith≈øtanding the caution u≈øed, both by the Dr.
and my≈øelf, to avoid a controver≈øy with epi≈øcopalians, they have ≈øeen fit to engage in one; and will not ≈øuffer us even to defend our cau≈øe, when called upon ≈øo to do, without taking the alarm; I ≈øhall not look upon my≈øelf holden to ob≈øerve the like caution, in that re≈øpect, as I did in my ≈øermon. If therefore in the cour≈øe of this di≈øpute, I ≈øhould happen to treat them with le≈øs ceremony: If there ≈øhould occa≈øionally drop from my pen, any direct reflections, or free animadver≈øions, upon ≈øome very exceptionable and un≈øcriptural parts of their ≈øcheme, when they fall in my way, I reque≈øt the candid reader to impute it to the proper cau≈øe.

div.head: SEC. I. Remarks upon the Letter-Writer, S. I. and Mr. L's Introduction.
div.p: MR. L. has u≈øhered his "defence" into public view, with a letter ≈øigned, S. I. Who this gentleman is, we are not concerned to enquire. As he has ≈øeen fit to give us only the initial letters of his name, and left us to gue≈øs the re≈øt; he mu≈øt expect no more ceremony than any anonymous writer, whatever honorary titles he may happen to be dignified with.

OUR opponents, ≈øays he, have of late, without any provocation, been mu≈øtering up their old ≈øophi≈øms again≈øt the ancient epi≈øcopal government of the church, which have been long ago abundantly an≈øwered over and over. Perhaps the gentleman thinks all arguments again≈øt his ≈øcheme, de≈øerve the name of ≈øophi≈øms. He ≈øhould remember however, that though to call an argument that pinches, by an ugly name, may be an ea≈øy method to get rid of it; yet in the judgment of the candid, a ≈øolid refutation would be more ≈øatisfactory. That our arguments are old, is readily granted; for ≈øo is truth: But that they are the wor≈øe or the weaker upon that account, appears not. Nor does it appear that the≈øe arguments have been all abundantly, I mean ≈øolidly an≈øwered. To pretend to an≈øwer an argument, is one
thing; to do it effectually, another. The former, in the pre≈øent ca≈øe, we allow. The latter perhaps wants proof: We have only his bare word for it; and as he ≈øeems to be an intere≈øted per≈øon, the public, and not he, will be pre≈øumed the propere≈øt judge. But then, The≈øe ≈øophi≈øms have been mu≈øtered up again≈øt the ancient epi≈øcopal government of the church. Had he ≈øaid again≈øt the pre≈øent government of the church of England, as explained by ≈øome of her zealous ≈øons; the words would have read as well, and been more agreeable to truth. Every ≈øect, almo≈øt, is apt to boa≈øt of its antiquity; and if bare a≈ø≈øertions are admitted as proof, one has as good a claim to the honour as another. That the pre≈øent government of the church of England, is epi≈øcopal, none will deny: But that it is very ancient, at lea≈øt ≈øo ancient as ≈øome of its advocates pretend, is by many denied. As to my≈øelf, I am fully per≈øuaded, that notwith≈øtanding all its high pretences to antiquity; it is comparatively a mere novel, up≈øtart in≈øtitution. So far from being the true ancient epi≈øcopacy, that prevailed in the apo≈øtles times, and the ages next following; that it is, in many re≈øpects, diametrically oppo≈øite to it and de≈øtructive of it. This, I pre≈øume, will appear in the following pages.

BUT after all, if we had attacked even the church of England, without provocation, it was doubtle≈øs wrong. This is a charge commonly brought by our epi≈øcopalians. Notwith≈øtanding the uncommon genero≈øity, with which they are treated in this country, and the ≈øingular indulgence of the ≈øtate towards them, above what was ever ≈øhewn to di≈ø≈øenters, in any part of the chri≈øtian world; they are often complaining of oppo≈øition and ill-u≈øage. At lea≈øt, if we will believe them, they never begin a controver≈øy. They are forced
into it, in their own defence. This gentleman tells us, the≈øe opponents, (meaning, I ≈øuppo≈øe, Dr. Chauncy and I) have of late been mu≈øtering, &c. again≈øt the church, without any provocation. Mr. L. ≈øays, I am fully per≈øuaded, upon the ≈øtricte≈øt enquiry, it will be found, that there cannot be one ≈øingle in≈øtance produced, for thirty years pa≈øt, in which our clergy have begun the di≈øpute. Defence, p. 7. And, When the church of England is attacked, her clergy ≈øuppo≈øe they ought to defend it. p. 8. His book is therefore called a defence, &c. And this is the only rea≈øon that cau≈øes him to publi≈øh this defence. But is this repre≈øentation hone≈øt? Are pre≈øbyterians ≈øuch quarrel≈øome neighbors, as always to be attacking the church of England? And beginning the controver≈øy with her, without provotion? Nothing le≈øs. The fir≈øt piece wrote upon the controver≈øy, in this country, was on the epi≈øcopal ≈øide. And the fir≈øt in this colony, by one with whom, I pre≈øume, S. I. is intimately acquainted. What then can the≈øe gentlemen mean, by attacks upon the church of England? Had either the Dr. or I, denied her the e≈ø≈øentials of a true church; had we di≈øputed the validity of her mini≈øtry;‚Äîpronounced a nullity upon her admini≈øtrations;‚Äîranked her clergy among the ≈øons of Korah, or her members with heathen Jews and infidels; or had we directly attempted to expo≈øe any of tho≈øe many things, which are, at lea≈øt, highly exceptionable in her doctrines, di≈øcipline, orders, and wor≈øhip; they might, with more propriety ≈øound the alarm, and cry, an attack upon the church. Every one knows, how common the≈øe cants are, from a certain quarter. But is there any thing of this kind in the pieces Mr.
L. pretends to an≈øwer? Certainly nothing. They bravely defend our mini≈øtry, from the exceptions of the≈øe zealous advocates for epi≈øcopacy, who≈øe high-flying principles, lead them to anathematize all of our communion, and leave all the prote≈øtant world, but them≈øelves, to the uncovenanted mercies of God. According to the≈øe gentlemen, it ≈øeems, there can be no defence of pre≈øbyterian principles, however mode≈øt, without attacking the church of England. This is a great mi≈øtake. Let but the church of England, even in her pre≈øent form, be put upon her original and true footing;‚Äî let her re≈øt upon the foundation, which the fir≈øt reformers, and all her moderate and catholic ≈øons ≈øince, have fixed for her; I mean the civil authority of the King and parliament; and they never need fear being attacked by us. A defence of pre≈øbytetian ordination and government, will be no direct oppo≈øition to the church of England, in this view of it. Had there never been any higher claims for her, (and, to me, it is clear there never oughts) Had her ≈øons in this country, contented them≈øelves, with challenging for her, the honour of being a valuable branch of the reformation, and of having the authority in England, engaged for her e≈øtabli≈øhment and ≈øupport there; I am confident, "the annual lecture in Cambridge," at which Mr. L. is ≈øo much nettled, never would have had a being; nor the pieces he pretends to an≈øwer, have ≈øeen the light.

BUT the grand ≈øecret no doubt is:‚ÄîThe cau≈øe of epi≈øcopacy is to be pu≈øhed in America, at all events. And, upon trial, this it ≈øeems, has been found the be≈øt expedient‚Äîto unhinge and perplex the minds of ignorant people,‚Äîto fill their heads with airy notions of the ab≈øolute nece≈ø≈øity of epi≈øcopal ordination, prejudice them again≈øt their own mini≈øters, as having no commi≈ø≈øion from Chri≈øt, no authority
to perform the divine offices of religion, and boldly pronouncing nullity upon all their admini≈øtrations. This is the general ≈øtrain of all the pieces upon the controver≈øy, that have been wrote in this country. If this was not Mr. L.'s de≈øign, he had no call to engage in the di≈øpute. This, however, is no new art. All oppo≈øers of religion, have ever made their mo≈øt ≈øucce≈øsful attacks, through the ≈øides of its clergy. Thus did Korah, Dathan and Abiram. They fell upon Mo≈øes and Aaron, and denied their authority, as officers in God's church. "Ye take too much upon you." The ≈øcribes and phari≈øees did the ≈øame in their oppo≈øition to chri≈øtianity in its infancy. They "compa≈ø≈øed ≈øea and land to make pro≈øelytes," they attacked the divine author of the go≈øpel, and boldly que≈øtioned his authority, as a public officer in the church. By what authority do≈øt thou the≈øe things? And who gave thee this authority? The apo≈øtle Paul met with the ≈øame treatment. The Judaizing teachers, (who, by the way, were notable ≈øticklers for unin≈øtituted rites and ceremonies in religion,) traduced his character, denied his mini≈øterial authority, and in that way endeavoured to prejudice people's mind, and draw off a party to follow them. This laid him often, under the di≈øagreeable nece≈ø≈øity, of vindicating him≈øelf again≈øt ≈øuch a≈øper≈øions; as may be ≈øeen in his epi≈øtles. The grand topic of declamation of papi≈øts, again≈øt prote≈øtants, has ever been this. MR. L. ≈øeems to be di≈øplea≈øed with the length of my ≈øermon. In page 30 he has the≈øe words, Tho' he (Mr. Welle's) fleers about our preaching deacons; yet I believe it is really true, that Stephen preached as good a ≈øermon as Mr. Welle's divine right, &c. though it was not ≈øo long. I hope he would not have me call it a real ≈øcriptural order of the mini≈øtry, when I did not believe it to be ≈øo, and had proved it not to be ≈øo.‚ÄîBut he believes it is really true, that Stephen preached as good a ≈øermon as mine, tho' it was not ≈øo long. I pre≈øume, will not pretend that all di≈øputing is preaching. He has di≈øputed again≈øt my ≈øermon; but he has not publicly told us, he ever preached again≈øt it, tho' others
≈øay he did at ≈øundry places and times. Whether his ≈øermon, upon the≈øe occa≈øions, was langer or ≈øherter, whether it was better or wor≈øe than mine, as it is of little importance, I am not anxious to know. For all he profe≈ø≈øedly attempts to an≈øwer of it, is only my fir≈øt argument, which being compri≈øed in little more than two pages, could not, one would think, give him any great pain.‚Äî Whether it was the length, or the ≈øtrength of the other arguments, that di≈øcouraged him from meddling with them; as he has not ≈øeen fit to tell us, every one mu≈øt be left to conjecture for him≈øelf.

THE pieces Mr. L. attempts to an≈øwer, had occa≈øionally mentioned "the right of people to choo≈øe their mini≈øters." When the vacancy made in the breach of apo≈øtles, by the ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ath of Judas, was to be ≈øupplied; the vote of the whole vi≈øible church there pre≈øent, was taken in the ca≈øe; ≈øo that when Matthias was appointed, he is ≈øaid to be numbered with the apo≈øties, by the common vote of ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ rage, as it is in the original. I mentioned in my ≈øermon, the in≈øtance of the ≈øeven deacons, who are expre≈ø≈øly ≈øaid,
‚Ä¢ o be cho≈øen by the church, by the whole ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ tionde. Act. 6.5. Was it tho't nece≈ø≈øary that the vote of the church ≈øhould be taken, in the choice of officers, who≈øe bu≈øine≈øs was only to ≈øerve tables; how much more, in the more important office, of mini≈øters of the word and ≈øacraments? Acts 14.23. Koiretona≈øantes, &c. which Beza venders, quumque ip≈øi per ≈øuffragin crea≈ø≈øent, &c. when they had by votes con≈øtituted them elders, &c. This, it ≈øeems, the tran≈ølators of our bible were convinced of. For before our Engli≈øh bibles had unthergone epi≈øcopul correction at this place, the words,
by election, were added. And in the margin was this note.‚ÄîThe apo≈øtles did not thru≈øt pa≈øtors into the church, by a lordly ≈øuperiority; but cho≈øe-and placed them, by the voice of the congregation. Rat. di≈ø. P. 27.

THESE now are ≈øo many ≈øcripture examples, of the exerci≈øe of this right, by the primitive chri≈øtians. Hence it undeniably follows, that this originally belonged to the people; con≈øoquently, ‚Ä¢ o go about to rob them of it, is un≈øcriptural and tyrannical. Dr. Chauncy mentioned a number of

To the≈øe, many more might ea≈øily be added, from the ≈øame quarter. I ≈øhall ≈øubjoin one from Cyprian, bi≈øhop of Carthage, who flouri≈øhed A.D. 250. Epil. 68. The ingenious author of the inquiry into the con≈øtitution, &c. of the primitive church, ≈øuppo≈øed to be Sr. Peter King, afterwards lord chancellor, abundantly proves, from numerous te≈øtimonies, that this was the univer≈øal practice of the primitive church, for people to choo≈øe their own mini≈øters. And indeed, the contrary practice is ≈øo repugnant to rea≈øon, to all notions of liberty, and the univer≈øal cu≈øtom in all other ca≈øes, that, one would think, nothing but the highe≈øt degree of prejudice could reconcile people to it. Do not we e≈øteem it a privilege to choo≈øe our civil rulers, and look upon the people as in a degree of ≈ølavery, who are utterly deprived of it? But if we are ≈øo tenacious of our natural rights, where our temporal intere≈øt and bodily health only are concerned,‚Äîhow much more ought we to be, in things that relate to the health of our ≈øouls, our future and eternal intere≈øt? Surely as much more, as the latter exceeds the former in point of importance. No wonder then Mr. L. con≈øidered the want of this, a very important objection again≈øt his favourite church; and though ≈øomewhat be≈øide
his ≈øubject, ≈øet him≈øelf ≈øo zealou≈øly to remove it. How far he has ≈øucceeded, I leave to the reader. But if he is not able, wholly, to vindicate his own church in this re≈øpect, he ≈øeems to think it ≈øome excu≈øe that others, and ours in particular, is in the ≈øame ≈øtate. This ≈øeems to be his meaning in the≈øe words: I believe if the matter be carefully examined, it will be found, that the right of the New-England churches, to choo≈øe their mini≈øters, is ≈øounded, not upon ≈øcripture, but upon the law of the province, which declares who ≈øhall be the patrons, in each pari≈øh to choo≈øe their mini≈øters. As far as I have been able to under≈øtand this matter, the law of the province con≈øtitutes the heads of the fami≈øies to choo≈øe, &c. P. 16.

How far Mr. L. has been able to under≈øtand this matter, he mu≈øt know be≈øt. The defect of his under≈øtanding, it is not in my power to help. Whether it was for want of under≈øtanding or will, certain, I am, the account he gives of this affair is not true. According to the law of this colony, (and I ≈øuppo≈øe the ca≈øe is much the ≈øame in the re≈øt of New-England, where there is an eccle≈øia≈øtical e≈øtabli≈øhment) the right of choo≈øing a mini≈øter, is declared to be, not in the heads of families exclu≈øively; but in them and the members of the church, whether heads of families or not. Be≈øides, this right is not founded, as he ≈øuppo≈øes, in the law of the colony, any more than the obligation of any divine law, adopted by the civil magi≈øtrate. And all men acquainted with our eccle≈øia≈øtical con≈øtitution, know that we are ≈øo far from having any thing to do, with what he calls patrons, in each pari≈øh,
to choo≈øe the mini≈øter; that mo≈øt people know nothing of the term, or what it ≈øignifies, and I hope, by experience, never may. The communicants, and all others of our people, who vote in ≈øociety-meetings for other purpo≈øes, have all free liberty to vote in the choice of a mini≈øter. And that they may act with di≈øcretion in this important affair; they have opportunity to make trial of the candidate while he is upon probation.‚Äî Was it then hone≈øt in Mr. L. to ≈øay, In the ≈øame way ≈øocieties, corporations and particular per≈øons, become patrons in the church of England? In that church, patrons, clerical or ≈øecular, choo≈øe the mini≈øters for the people. In ours, he is cho≈øen by the church and people them≈øelves. In the former the bi≈øhop, or ≈øome lay patron, who perhaps never ≈øaw the candidate, and is never to fit under his mini≈øtry, has the ≈øole power of electing. In the latter, he is elected by the votes of tho≈øe who have made trial of him, are to maintain him, and attend upon his admini≈øtrations. In our method, the law acknowledges the natural and ≈øcriptural right of the people in this important affair, and protects them in the enjoyment of it. But in theirs, in defiance of both, their mini≈øter is obtruded upon them without their con≈øent. If therefore, in this view of the ca≈øe, that good gentleman, (as Mr. L. calls the Dr.) ≈øhould really think their church, ≈øomewhat culpable in the matter of patrons; few people, I pre≈øume, "would greatly wonder at it," ≈øave he and tho≈øe of his party; and if, as he ≈øays, their church appears to him to ≈øtand clear of all blame in that matter; it mu≈øt be owing, I think, to prejudice and partiality in a very high degree.

I FIND but one thing more, in Mr. L's book, proper for this ≈øection. And that is, the uncommon adverti≈øement tacked to the end of it. I have read it over ≈øundry times, but can't be certain I have
hit upon his meaning after all. He talks much about con≈øequences; cautions his an≈øwerer again≈øt "falling upon con≈øequences," and declares that he "has no concern with con≈øequences." What he intends by them, is difficult to ≈øay. A con≈øequence in logic, is an e≈ø≈øential part of every good argument. But he can't mean this by his con≈øequences: For whatever they be, he places them in oppo≈øition to arguments, for want of which, in confuting his book, they are ≈øuppo≈øed to be "fallen upon." But if this be his meaning, he need give him≈øelf no trouble in the ca≈øe, provided he has only been careful, "to advance" nothing but truth: For truth is ever con≈øi≈øtent with it≈øelf; and nothing but truth will follow from it, or be the con≈øequence of it, and this can do him no hurt. But if he has not: If he has advanced things in his book, that are not true, or e≈øpou≈øed principles that can
‚Ä¢ ot be ≈øupported by ≈øcripture or rea≈øon, he mu≈øt ‚Ä¢ e accountable for the con≈øequences, whether he will or no. If, for in≈øtance, he has advanced a ≈øcheme of church government, which takes the power of di≈øcipline out of the hands of her proper pa≈øtors, and ≈øo robs her of this u≈øeful part of Chri≈øt's in≈øtitution: If, according to his principles, the epi≈øcopal churches in America, cannot be ≈øaid to have the lea≈øt ≈øhadow of di≈øcipline: If it nece≈ø≈øarily follows from his po≈øitions, that it is better to be a papi≈øt than a pre≈øbyterian, and an ordination received in the church of Rome, "the mother of harlots" is lawful and valid, while one received in the truly prote≈øtant church of Scotland or Geneva, is ip≈øo facto nul and void. Of the unaccountable partiality of the church of England in favor of Rome, there has not long ≈øince, as I am informed, been a ≈øtriking in≈øtance in America. Mr. Houdon a Romi≈øh prie≈øt in Canada, took a fancy to a young lady. As the doctrine of celibacy in his church, forbid his marrying of her, they agreed to quit their country and run off to New York. Sometime after he found means to get recommended to the ≈øociety for propagating the go≈øpel, and without re-ordination, came as a mi≈øtionary in their ≈øervice to New-Rochelle, where he lately died. Much about the ≈øame time, as I take it, Mr. Hooper, who had been ordained in the church of Scotland, conformed to the church, but could not be admitted as a mini≈øter without ‚Ä¢ e ordination. He accordingly went to England, was re ordained by the bi≈øhop and is now an epi≈øcopal mini≈øter in one of the churches in Bo≈øton. If upon his ≈øcheme, all the prote≈øtant world, except his own church, For the Note above referred to, ≈øee page 36.
are utterly de≈øtitute of any valid go≈øpel adminiltrations, and in no better ≈øtate than heathen and infidels, becau≈øe they lack epi≈øcopal ordination: Or la≈øtly, if he ≈øhould be told, that upon his principles, both he, and probably the greate≈øt part of epi≈øcopalians in this country, are in the ≈øame deplorable circum≈øtances; having never received any bapti≈øm, but what was admini≈øtered by the u ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
thorized hands of tho≈øe, who lack epi≈øcopal ordination, and therefore, upon his princples, can have no power to baptize, con≈øequently, that he, and the greate≈øt part of his brother-mi≈ø≈øionaries in the≈øe parts, are ≈øo far from being the only authorized regular mini≈øters among us, that they are not even vi≈øible chri≈øtians, and therefore, not only, have no right to admini≈øter go≈øpel ordinances to others, but are actually unintitled to them them≈øelves:‚Äî If any, or all the≈øe things ≈øhould happen to be urged again≈øt him, perhaps he will call it "a flying from the ≈øubject, and falling upon con≈øequences."‚Äî And in an≈øwer, gravely tell us, "he has no concern with con≈øequences." But whatever he thinks, impartial judges, 'tis pre≈øumed, will think, that
genuine cen≈øequences, may properly be urged in a di≈øpute, without being chargeable with "flying from the ≈øubject for want of argument;" and that the advocates of ≈øuch principles, from whence ≈øuch con≈øequences flow, ought to be "concerned" about them, whether they be or no. No man ≈øhould advance any principles, but what are true. From ≈øuch, no con≈øequences will follow but what are true, and con≈øequently good: Good in them≈øelves, and agreeable to every doctrine and duty of ≈øcripture, which is infallible truth. If therefore men find, their principles are productive of con≈øequences, in their own nature, bad; repugnant to the laws of charity and the great doctrines and duties of the go≈øpel; they cannot think to excu≈øe them≈øelves to the world, by ≈øaying "they have no concern with con≈øequences." They ought to be "concerned about them," and manife≈øt this concern to the world, by renouncing and abjuring ≈øuch principles, as corrupt and dete≈øtable, from which ≈øuch uncharitable and damnatory con≈øequences follow.

div.head: SEC. III. Animadver≈øions upon Mr. L's preliminary Remarks to page 10.
div.p:
IN the mean time, let us attend to the ob≈øervations he thinks proper to make, previous to his entering upon this deci≈øion. His fir≈øt ob≈øervation is this, The whole body of di≈ø≈øenters, (pre≈øbyterians he means) affirm, that bi≈øhop and pre≈øbyter, in ≈øcripture, ≈øignify the ≈øame office: Yet they ≈øay, no in≈øtance is to be found there of an ordination, by any per≈øon unde, the name bi≈øhop: And if a pre≈øbyter is the ≈øame office, then there is none by a pre≈øbyter. ibid. But now, who does not ≈øee the fallacy of this argument? He allows, with us, that bi≈øhop and pre≈øbyter in ≈øcripture, ≈øignify the ≈øame office; that mini≈øters were promi≈øcuou≈øly called by both the≈øe names, in go≈øpel times. But then he holds, that the bu≈øine≈øs of ordination, &c. ought not to lie in common, to all go≈øpel-mini≈øters; but to be confined to a particular order, which in their church, are called bi≈øhops. We, on the contrary affirm, that as bi≈øhop and pre≈øbyter, in ≈øcripture, ≈øignify the ≈øame office; the power of ordination belongs in common to all mini≈øters, and therefore ought not to be confined
to ≈øome few, under the title of bi≈øhops. To prove this, we ob≈øerve, that though we have ≈øundry accounts of ordination, in ≈øcripture, performed by mini≈øters, yet there is no ≈øingle in≈øtance of one ≈øo performed by them, under the name bi≈øhop, and yet to this, epi≈øcopalians appropriate the whole power of ordination. But Mr. L. ≈øays, if this be true, that there is no account in ≈øcripture of an ordination performed by any per≈øon under the name bi≈øhop, then it will follow,‚ÄîWhat? Why "that there is none by a pre≈øbyter," that is, no in≈øtance of one performed by a pre≈øbyter. But does it at all follow, that becau≈øe the ≈øcripture mentions no ordination as performed by mini≈øters under their one title of bi≈øhops, therefore there is no in≈øtance to be found there of their ordaining under their other title, that of pre≈øbyters? Or thus, becau≈øe the ≈øcripture never calls mini≈øters by one of their common names, i. e. bi≈øhops, when acting in ordination; is it a nece≈ø≈øary con≈øequence that it never calls them by their other common name, pre≈øbyters, when acting in that bu≈øine≈øs? Is it not po≈ø≈øible that the ≈øame office in ≈øcripture, may be commonly denominated and known by either of the names, bi≈øhop or pre≈øbyter indifferently, and yet only one of the≈øe names, con≈øtantly u≈øed and applied to him, when acting in the bu≈øine≈øs of ordination? But now this is what his argument proves, or el≈øe it proves nothing. The truth is, he has, either ignorantly or de≈øignedly, altered the terms in his ≈øyllogi≈øm, ≈øo that his conclu≈øion contains more in it than his premi≈øes, which all logicians call, fal≈øe rea≈øoning.‚Äî His argument reduced to mode and figure, runs thus, Bi≈øhop and pre≈øbyter in ≈øcripture ≈øignify the ≈øame office. No in≈øtance is to be found there of ordination by any per≈øon under the name of bi≈øhop. This is his major and minor propo≈øition. His conclu≈øion is,‚ÄîTherefore there is no in≈øtance of an ordination performed
by a pre≈øbyter. Whereas, had he kept to the terms in his minor propo≈øition, his conclu≈øion mu≈øt have been,‚Äî"Therefore there is no in≈øtance of an ordination performed by any per≈øon under the name pre≈øbyter." Had he done this, his readers would at once have ≈øeen the weakne≈øs and fallacy of his argument.

IN England, bi≈øhop, and lord-≈øpiritual are ≈øynonymous terms. Now ≈øhould I undertake to prove, that there is no account in the Engli≈øh hi≈øory, of an ordination performed by a bi≈øhop, and in order to it, make u≈øe of this argument,‚ÄîBi≈øhop and lord-≈øpiritual ≈øignify the ≈øame office: But there is no account in hi≈øtory, of an ordination performed by any per≈øon under the title of lord-≈øpiritual; therefore there is no account of one performed by a bi≈øhop; and from hence ≈øhould infer, the invalidity of epi≈øcopal ordination; Mr. L. I pre≈øume would hardly allow the argument to be good.‚Äî And yet it is the ≈øame he has u≈øed in this ca≈øe, and full as conclu≈øive. However, weak as it is, it ≈øeems it wrought full conviction in his mind: For he tells us he is fully per≈øuaded, at that time in which the ≈øcriptures were wrote, none had power to ordain mini≈øters in Chri≈øt's kingdom, but tho≈øe only who in ≈øcripture, are called apo≈øtles.
Page 9. But then what becomes of bi≈øhop Timothy? Mr. L. has ≈øpent a con≈øiderable part of his book in attempting to prove, the divine right of epi≈øcopacy, from the in≈øtance of Timothy bi≈øhop of Ephe≈øus. Yea it is the mo≈øt plau≈øible argument, and indeed the only thing in his piece that de≈øerves the name of an argument. But if none had power to ordain mini≈øters in Chri≈øt's kingdom, but tho≈øe only, who are in ≈øcripture called apo≈øtles, Timothy certainly had no power to ordain, for he is never once called „Äà‚óä„Äâ
apo≈øtle in the whole ≈øcripture, as I ≈øhall have occa≈øion more particularly to ≈øhew anon: Con≈øequently all pretence to ≈øupport his ≈øcheme from this argument is to no purpo≈øe. BUT how does he prove "that di≈ø≈øenters are not agreed" in this point? Why he tells us, "≈øome never ordain their deacons," and the≈øe of cour≈øe

BUT he tells u ‚Ä¢ , In ≈øcripture we find mention made of apo≈øtles, pre≈øbyters, and deacons, and why they ≈øhould be ≈øo carefully di≈øtingui≈øhed whenever they are mentioned in ≈øcripture, if there was not a ≈øubordination in their office, ≈øeems very ≈øtrange. HOWEVER, that there is mention made, in ≈øcripture, of apo≈øtles, pre≈øbyters and deacons, is readily granted. HE goes on.‚ÄîLet it be carefully remarked, that tho≈øe who were commi≈ø≈øioned to ≈øend others, who were called apo≈øtles, in the time when the New-Te≈øtament was penned. P. 10. div.head: SEC. IV. Dr. Chauncy's ≈øermon vindicated from the exceptions contained in the "de≈øence of epi≈øcopacy,"‚Äîfrom p. 11 to 24.
div.p: BEFORE I enter upon a vindication of the Dr's ≈øermon, from the exceptions of another, it concerns me to do him ju≈øtice, in one particular, in which I have, inadvertently, mi≈ørepre≈øented him my≈øelf.

WHEN I wrote this ≈øentence, I had my mind upon what the Dr. ≈øays, in p. 71 of his ≈øermon: But upon reviewing the pa≈ø≈øage, I find, I mi≈øtook his meaning. His words are not that tho≈øe epi≈øtles ≈øpeak very fully in favour of dioce≈øan epi≈øcopacy: But that they do, as certainly, as ≈øtrongly, and as con≈øtantly, di≈øtingui≈øh bi≈øhops from pre≈øbyters, as any of the writings of the third and fourth centuries. Now all that the Dr. a≈ø≈øerts is, that the≈øe epi≈øtles point out a di≈øtinction of order between bi≈øhop and pre≈øbyter: And upon reading what Mr. Boy≈øe has wrote, in his "clear account of the ancient epi≈øcopacy," in which he has every thing contained in the≈øe epi≈øles, relative to the ≈øubject; I am fully convinced, that the bi≈øhop de≈øcribed in the≈øe epi≈øtles, even in the pre≈øent ≈øtate of them, is very different from
the dioce≈ø ‚Ä¢ n bi≈øhop. The Ignatian bi≈øhop, was merely a parochial one, having no more than a ≈øingle congregation for his charge, with pre≈øbyters under him: Whereas the dioce≈øan one, has many ≈øcores, or hundreds of ≈øuch congregations in his cure. The interpolations and adulterations in the≈øe ‚Ä¢ pi≈øtles, were doubtle≈øs made, before the bi≈øhops power was enlarged, ≈øo as to comprehend a number of pari≈øhes in his dioce≈øe.‚ÄîHaving thus corrected my own mi≈øtake; I proceed to perform the ≈øame friendly office as to Mr. L.

As a direct proof of ordination by pre≈øbyters, the Dr. had mentioned, the in≈øtance of Saul and Barnabas being ≈øeparated to the work of the mini≈øtry, by certain prophets and teachers, as recorded, Acts xiii. beginning. As this is ≈øo very expre≈øs and circum≈øtantial an account, of a ≈øeparation to the work of the mini≈øtry; as all the ≈øolemn actions, contained in ordination, are here ≈øo particularly mentioned; and as this is ≈øaid to be done, not by apo≈øtles or bi≈øhops, but by the ordinary pa≈øtors of the church, here called prophets and teachers; Mr. L. ≈øeems to be at a lo≈øs what reply to make to it. He, at fir≈øt, ≈øeems to be doubtful as to the nature of this action; at a lo≈øs what name to give it. "If, ≈øays he, this was an ordination:" "If this was a real ordination, then," &c. Finally, he denies it to be an ordination. Whatever is meant, ≈øays he, by this de≈øignation, it was not an ordination. In truth this was not an ordination. P. 11. He found him≈øelf ≈øo pre≈ø≈øed with this in≈øtance, that he had no way to get rid of the argument, but by flatly denying it to be an ordination. And indeed, this was the only cour≈øe he could take to ≈øupport his ≈øcheme. For if this be once granted to be a real ordination, the indi≈øputable right of pre≈øbyters, to act in this bu≈øine≈øs, is firmly e≈øtabli≈øhed, and all pretences of
confining it to a ≈øuperior order, mu≈øt be given up. I ≈øhall therefore offer a few ob≈øervations, to prove that this was, in fact, an ordination; and then make ≈øome remarks upon Mr. L.'s objections again≈øt its being con≈øidered as ≈øuch.

Now by ordination, I conclude, is meant, a ≈øolemn ≈øeperation, or ≈øetting apart to an office in the church, by ≈øuch as have authority to do it, and that, in the u≈øe of tho≈øe rites or actions, the ≈øcripture has appointed in this ca≈øe. The ≈øcripture rites of ordination, are fa≈øting, prayer, and the impo≈øition of hands. In this way the ≈øeven deacons were introduced into office, Acts vi. 6. which Mr. L. owns to be an ordination. In the ≈øame way Timothy was ordained. 1 Tim. iv. 14. And in the ≈øame way he is directed to ordain others. 1 Tim. v. 22. And this has been the general method of introducing men into the mini≈øtry, in all ≈øub≈øequent ages. But now, all the≈øe things concurred in the in≈øtance under con≈øideration. The per≈øons acting in it, were church officers of Antioch, "prophets and teachers." What they undertook to do, was to "≈øeperate Saul and Barnabas to the work of the mini≈øtry, among the gentiles." This was done by the direction of the holy Gho≈øt; ≈øeperate me Barnabas and Saul to the work, where unto I have called them; that is, to the work of the mini≈øtry, e≈øpecially among the gentiles, to whom they were now ≈øent. The thing therefore to be done, beyond di≈øpute, was to ≈øeperate the≈øe two men to the work of the go≈øpel mini≈øtry. How this was done, the account informs „Äà‚óä„Äâ ; For when they had fa≈øted and prayed and laid their hands on them, they ≈øent them away. As every action, every circum≈øtance pertaining to an ordination, is here ≈øo very particularly and expre≈ø≈øly found; if after all, this was not an ordination, I di≈øpair of
ever finding one, in ≈øcripture or any where el≈øe. And what ≈øtill further confirms the matter, if it needs further confirmation, is, that if I am not much mi≈øtaken, the apo≈øtle Paul him≈øelf acknowledges it to be ≈øo. In his in≈øcription of his epi≈øtle to the Romans, chap. i. 5.1. he has the≈øe words, Paul a ≈øervant of Je≈øus Chri≈øt, called to be an apo≈øtle, ≈øeperated to the go≈øpel of God. He here evidently de≈øigns to give him≈øelf, his true and proper character, of an apo≈øtle, and mini≈øter of Je≈øus Chri≈øt. He therefore particularly mentions, both his call to the apo≈øtle≈øhip, and his ≈øeperation to the go≈øpel mini≈øtry. By the former, he mo≈øt likely means that immediate call from heaven, of which in Acts ix. Then it was he was called to be an apo≈øtle. But we find nothing in ≈øcripture an≈øwering to this other part of his character, viz. his ≈øeperation to the go≈øpel of God, unle≈øs it was this ≈øeperation we are now con≈øidering. And it is worthy of remark, the word in both places is the ≈øame, both in the original, and al≈øo in our tran≈ølation. In Acts 13th, The holy Gho≈øt ≈øaid, APHORISATE, ≈øeperate me Barnabas and Saul to the work whereunto I have called them. In Rom. i. 1. The apo≈øtle, ≈øays he, "was, APHORISMENOS, ≈øeperated to the go≈øpel of God." Does it not appear highly probable, that when the apo≈øtle wrote the≈øe la≈øt mentioned words, he had his mind particularly upon the action we are con≈øidering? I confe≈øs I ≈øee no other ≈øen≈øe in which they can be well interpreted. And if ≈øo, we have the te≈øtimony, even of the apo≈øtle him≈øelf, that this was, in fact, an ordination.

To this Mr. L. objects, that if the≈øe prophets and teachers were pre≈øbyters, ≈øo were Barnabas and Saul. And if this was an ordination, they, who were before pre≈øbyters, were ordained to a ≈øuperior office; which, he ≈øays, is granting the thing they contend for. I an≈øwer. Tho' Saul, and po≈ø≈øibly Barnabas too, were in office, as
apo≈øtles; yet there is no account, that either they or indeed any others, had been formally introduced into office, as ≈øtanding mini≈øters in the church, by the impo≈øition of hands, till now. They, and the re≈øt of the apo≈øtles, had hitherto, exerci≈øed their mini≈øtry, principally among the Jews. But now, that the go≈øpel was to be ≈øent to the Gentiles, and churches gathered and ≈øettled among them, upon a plan which was to be perpetuated, after the times of in≈øpiration were over, even to the end of the world; it ≈øeemed good to the Holy Gho≈øt, to order, that they ≈øhould be ≈øet apart, by the ≈øolemn rite of ordination, as a ≈øtanding pattern for the≈øe future ages. This, as Dr. Chauncy ob≈øerved, was the opinion of a learned epi≈øcopal writer, Dr. Lightfoot. No better rea≈øon, ≈øays he, can be given of this pre≈øent action; than that the Lord did hereby, ≈øet down a platform of ordaining mini≈øters, to the church of the Gentiles in former times. Vol. l. p. 189. This being the ca≈øe, it will by no means follow, that, "if this was an ordination, they were ordained to a ≈øuperior office," as he ≈øuppo≈øes. Tho' they were in office before, they had been only "called to be apo≈øtles;" whereas now, they were "≈øeparated to the go≈øpel of God," by ordination, that ≈øo they might, both have a public authentic character, and exhibit a pattern to be followed, in all ≈øucceeding ages. Had Mr. L's head been le≈øs crowded, with the un≈øcriptural ideas of ≈øuperiority and inferiority of orders in the mini≈øtry, he might have recollected, that even reordination it≈øelf, does not nece≈ø≈øarily "advance a man to a ≈øuperior office in the church." ‚ÄîHe doubtle≈øs knows ≈øundry of his brethren in America, who have been twice ordained: Once, "by the hands of the pre≈øbytery," according to ≈øcripture pattern, and then again by the bi≈øhop, after they conformed to his church: And yet I
≈øuppo≈øe, he acknowledges them ≈øtill, as ≈øu≈øtaining no higher office, than that of pre≈øbyters. Tho' according to his argument, he ought, in all rea≈øon, to look upon them as dignitaries in the church; for who, (to u≈øe his own words) ever heard, that a pre≈øbyter was ordained, unle≈øs it was, to advance him to a higher ≈øtation in the church?

BUT In truth, ≈øays he, this was not an ordination, but an ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ cion of the ≈ø ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ nature with that, Gal. ii. 9. When James, Cephas and John, &c. It is well, ≈øince he will not allow this to be an ordination, he has at la≈øt found what it is. It ≈øeems then, that it was "giving the right hand of fellow≈øhip:" For that is what was done in the in≈øtance to which he compares it. Now giving the right hand of fellow≈øhip, as it is a public declaration and ≈øign, that the per≈øon to whom it is given, is now received into a co-partner≈øhip of power and office with the givers, mu≈øt nece≈ø≈øarily ≈øuppo≈øe that the per≈øons giving, are at lea≈øt, equal in power with him who receives it. Con≈øequently if what was now done, was, as he ≈øays, giving the right hand of fellow≈øhip to Barnabas and Saul, it will follow that the≈øe prophets and teachers were at lea≈øt equal in power to Barnabas and Saul. Since therefore, Mr. L. allows the ordaining power to the latter, it mu≈øt equally belong to the former, whether they did in fact exerci≈øe it at this time or no; and then the validity of ordination by pre≈øbyters will of cour≈øe follow.

AGAIN. If the≈øe two actions are, as he ≈øays, both of the ≈øame nature, then it will follow, tha ‚Ä¢ the per≈øons acting in both were of the ≈øame office, or indued with equal power: But tho≈øe who gave the right hand, in Gal. ii. 9. viz. James, Cephas and John, were undoubtedly ve≈øted with the ordaining power, for they were apo≈øtles: Con≈øequently the prophets and teachers, who acted in the other in≈øtance, mu≈øt be ve≈øted with the ≈øame

IF this an≈øwer will not ≈øatisfy Mr. L. I will give him another, in the words of a prote≈øtant in an≈øwer to a demand of the like kind from a papi≈øt. It is as follows. OR if this account ≈øhould be thought of too late a date, I will refer him to that given by Jerom, one of the fathers. His words are the≈øe:‚ÄîThe pre≈øbyter therefore is the ≈øame with the bi≈øhop. I FIND nothing more, by way of remark, upon the Dr's ≈øermon, in the whole of Mr. L's book, except a pa≈ø≈øage or two towards the clo≈øe, which ≈øhall be con≈øidered in their place. I therefore fini≈øh this ≈øection with this rea≈øonable reque≈øt;‚Äîthat the Dr's ≈øermon, our author's remarks upon it, and what has been now offered in reply, be carefully read over and compared. If this is done, I pre≈øume, that no one except Mr. L. and his partial admirers will be of the mind, "that he has, as he ‚Ä¢ cerms it, con≈øidered the mo≈øt material things advanced by the Dr. in ≈øupport of his ≈øcheme," muchle≈øs, "that he has ≈øhewn him to be greatly mi≈øtaken in many things he has a≈ø≈øerted."Page 27. And as to tho≈øe few that are touched upon; the objections are ≈øo far from being conclu≈øive, that they are really of no weight at all.

div.head: SEC. V. Reflections upon Mr. L's claim of an uninterrupted ≈øucce≈ø≈øion from the apo≈øtles, e≈øpecially thro' the line of the old Briti≈øh bi≈øhops;‚Äîfrom p. 24, to 27.

WHAT could induce our author, to fall upon this topic of the uninterrupted ≈øucce≈ø≈øion, and ≈øet him≈øelf to an≈øwer objections again≈øt epi≈øcopacy, which neither of the pieces he undertakes to confute, ≈øay any thing about; and at the ≈øame time, pa≈øs over unnoticed, ≈øo great a part

I HAVE ≈øometimes heard it remarked, indeed, as a fort of incon≈øi≈øtency in the church of England, to di≈øcover ≈øuch a partial affection to that of Rome, as to allow of their orders as valid while they deny tho≈øe of all prote≈øtant churches; and boa≈øt ≈øo much of a ≈øucce≈ø≈øion through that church, which in their homilies they call "a filthy old withered harlot, and ≈øo far from being of the nature of a true church, that for more than nine hundred years before the reformation, nothing could be more." This, however, Mr. L. denies. They did not, he ≈øays, derive either their power, or chri≈øtiamity from Rome. "The Briti≈øh church flouri≈øhed, he tells us, many hundred years‚Äîbefore the go≈øpel took place in England." I an≈øwer:‚ÄîThat chri≈øtianity was early introduced into England, is not denied. Who fir≈øt preached it there, is very uncertain. 'Tis ≈øtill more ≈øo in what form, whether pre≈øbyterian or epi≈øcopalian, that church was fir≈øt ≈øettled. If Paul was the fir≈øt who brought the go≈øpel to Britain and planted chri≈øtianity there, as many writers ≈øay; it is pre≈øumed, that ≈øince he him≈øelf was ordained by pre≈øbyters, that was the form of ordination and government he would e≈øtabli≈øh there. As to king Lucius, whom Mr. L. makes to be the fir≈øt chri≈øtian king, and the founder of an arch-bi≈øhoprick in London; the time of his conver≈øion is ≈øo uncertain, that Fuller, in his church hi≈øtory, reckons up no le≈øs than twenty≈øix different accounts of it by different writers; between the fir≈øt and la≈øt of which, there is no le≈øs
than 90 years difference, as to date.Ch. Hi≈øt. p. 10. This, with many other things mentioned by the ≈øame author gives the whole ≈øuch a fabulous and romantic a ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ that there is little or no weight to be laid on a ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ thing ≈øaid about him. And indeed many doubt whether there ever was ≈øuch a man in the world.

BUT granting chri≈øtianity was as early planted i ‚Ä¢ G. Britain, as he pretends, this will by no mean help him out with a ≈øucce≈ø≈øion thro' the old Briti≈øh bi≈øhops, as di≈øtinct from tho≈øe of the Romi≈ø ‚Ä¢ church. He allows that the pope "got footing in England before the reformation." But then „Äà‚óä„Äâ tells us "the old Briti≈øh clergy oppo≈øed him with all their might, and prevented all that came from Rome, from getting into the vacant churches, „Äà‚óä„Äâ far as po≈ø≈øibly they could." That when the fir≈øt opportunity pre≈øented, at the time of the reformation "they threw off the papal yoke." All that we ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ "ordained at Rome, he tells us, refu≈øing to comply with the reformation, returned to Rome, from whence they came. The number of bi≈øhops th ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ did ≈øo were fourteen. The re≈øt of the bi≈øhop who were ordained, and derived their power by „Äà‚óä„Äâ regular ≈øucce≈ø≈øion of ordinations from the ancient Briti≈øh bi≈øhops, were the men who ordained the bi≈øhops and pre≈øbyters of our church."P. 2 ‚Ä¢ . I have tran≈øcribed the whole of this curious piece of ≈øecret hi≈øtory, that the reader may have it all in one view.

IT is well known, by all acquainted with the Engli≈øh hi≈øtory, that Au≈øtin the monk came into England toward the latter end of the ≈øixth century. He was ≈øent there by Gregory, the pope „Äà‚óä„Äâ Rome, to convert the Anglo-≈øaxons to chri≈øtianity. From that time to the reformation, A. D. 1530, a ≈øpace of near a thou≈øand years, England was under the popi≈øh yoke, and over-run with all the errors and ≈øuper≈øtitions of the church of Rome, „Äà‚óä„Äâ much as the re≈øt of Europe. The whole chri≈øtiansCor. geo. gram. p. 213.
world, for many hundred years before the reformation, "wandered after the bea≈øt;" and the church of England, during the whole of that period, was as much „Äà‚óä„Äâ church of Rome, as that of France, Spain, or even Italy it≈øelf. All equally ≈øunk in error, ≈øuper≈øtition, and idolatry, and equally "drunk with the cup of abominations, and filthine≈øs of the fornications, of that old withered harlot." Where then, I a≈øk, will Mr. L. find a ≈øucce≈ø≈øion for their clergy, except through the bi≈øhops of the Romi≈øh church? His attempts to derive it through a line of "ancient Briti≈øh bi≈øhops," is a mere chimera, that ≈øcarce de≈øerves notice. There were no ≈øuch bi≈øhops to be found in England, during the greate≈øt part of that time. I readily allow that chri≈øtianity had been planted in England, before Au≈øtin's arrival; that upon the Saxon inva≈øion, a number of the Briti≈øh chri≈øtians retired into the mountains of Wales, and pre≈øerved their liberty and chri≈øtianity. It is further granted, that upon Au≈øtin's coming into England, the old Briti≈øh clergy in Wales, refu≈øed at fir≈øt to ≈øubmit to the Pope's authority. In con≈øequence of which the greate≈øt part of them were cruelly put to the ≈øword, in the city of Bangor, ≈øaid to be effected by Au≈øtin's means.Full. ch. Hi≈øt. lib. 2, page 63. The remainder were too incon≈øiderable a handful to make any oppo≈øition to Au≈øtin, who was commi≈ø≈øioned by the Roman pontiff, and ≈øupported by the power of the Saxon kings, ≈øundry of whom are ≈øaid to be his early converts. If the≈øe Welch bi≈øhops therefore, were tho≈øe Mr. L. means by his "ancient Briti≈øh bi≈øhops" from whom their clergy derive their ≈øucce≈ø≈øion, and who he tells us "as far as po≈ø≈øible, prevented all that came from Rome from getting into the vacant churches;" the oppo≈øition they made, could be but very feeble at be≈øt, and mu≈øt certainly have
cea≈øed, after the greate≈øt part of them were cut off. And as to the remainder of them we are a≈ø≈øured from hi≈øtory, that they ≈øoon after ≈øubmitted to the church of Rome: "For Laurentius, who ≈øucceeded Au≈øtin, as arch-bi≈øhop of Canterbury, by demeaning him≈øelf more humbly, that his predece≈ø≈øor had done, reduced the re≈øcuent Britons to ≈øome tolerable conformity to the Romi≈øh ceremonies."Ful. ch. Hi≈øt. page 68. And ≈øo entirely were the ancient Britons, brought under the eccle≈øia≈øtical dominion of the Romi≈øh church of England, that about A. D. 1279, near three hundred years before the reformation, "John Peckham, arch-bi≈øhop of Canterbury, actually excommunicated their prince, becau≈øe he could not prevail upon him to be at peace with England."id. Lib. 3, p. 78. In about three or four years after this, king Edward the fir≈øt, intirely conquered Wales, beheaded I hewellin ap Griffith their la≈øt king, after he had taken him pri≈øoner.Salm. geo. gram. p. 354. Since which time, Wales, the la≈øt re≈øort of the ancient Britons, has been annexed to England, as part of the kingdom, and incorporated with it, in all affairs civil and ecclie≈øtical. What then can Mr. L. mean, by pretending to keep up a di≈øtinction between the Briti≈øh clergy, and tho≈øe of the Romi≈øh church? Wales, for many hundred years before the reformation, was as really under the "papal yoke," as he terms it, and received their bi≈øhops "from Rome" as much as any other part of the kingdom.

BUT if this had not been the ca≈øe: Had it been, as his argument ≈øuppo≈øes, that there was a di≈øtinct ≈øucce≈ø≈øion of bi≈øhops kept up in Wales, in a direct line from the ancient Briti≈øh bi≈øhops, even till the reformation; this will afford him no manner of relief as to the pre≈øent clergy of their church. They, certainly, can claim no benefit from ≈øuch a ≈øucce≈ø≈øion of Welch bi≈øhops; for not one of the
Welch bi≈øhops was concerned in the con≈øecration of Parker, and yet from him all the bi≈øhops in the church of England ever ≈øince mu≈øt derive their ≈øucce≈ø≈øion. The fact was truly this. In the beginning of the reformation under Henry VIII. all the bi≈øhops, abbots and priors in England, (Fi≈øher bi≈øhop of Roche≈øter only excepted) complied with it, as far as it was then carried.Burn. eccl. hi≈øt. abridg. vol 1, page 106. This therefore, could not be the time Mr. L. ≈øpeaks of, "when all that were ordained at Rome, refu≈øed to comply with the reformation, and returned to Rome from whence they came." For at this time none returned to Rome; and but one in the whole kingdom, refu≈øed to comply with the changes that were made. By the reformation, therefore, he mu≈øt mean, the revival of it in Queen Elizabeth's reign. Then indeed, all the bi≈øhops in the kingdom, except Kitchen of Landaff, refu≈øed to comply with it and were turned out. None of them, however, "returned to Rome, as he a≈ø≈øerts, ≈øave one only, and but three left the kingdom, viz. Pates, bi≈øhop of Worche≈øter, Scot of Che≈øter, and Goldwell of St. A≈øaph.id. vol. 2, p. 332. Ful. ch. hi≈øt. B. 8, p. 58. This is con≈øiderably ≈øhort of the number fourteen, mentioned by Mr. L. Now this being the ca≈øe, that all the bi≈øhops in the kingdom, not only of England, but Wales too, except one, were deprived; where will he go to make out a ≈øucce≈ø≈øion for their clergy, from the old Briti≈øh bi≈øhops? They were all, ≈øave one, deprived, and a new ≈øucce≈ø≈øion begun in Parker, from whom all the bi≈øhops ever ≈øince, mu≈øt derive their claim. Unle≈øs therefore, he can prove, that Parker was con≈øecrated by the de≈øcendants of tho≈øe "ancient Briti≈øh bi≈øhops," his pretended ≈øucce≈ø≈øion from them, is inevitably overthrown. But to the utter de≈øtruction of his ≈øcheme, ≈øo it happened, that Parker, (from-whom all the clergy of the church
of England, both bi≈øhops and pre≈øbyters, ever ≈øince, derive their ≈øucce≈ø≈øion) was con≈øecrated, not by any of the bi≈øhops of Wales, but by four Engli≈øh bi≈øhops, who had been con≈øecrated in king Edward's time, had been deprived in the reign of Queen Mary, and had never been re≈øtored. For the men who con≈øecrated Parker, were Barlow, formerly bi≈øhop of Bath and Wells, Scory of Chiche≈øter, Coverdale of Exeter, and Hodg≈økins fu≈øfragan of Bedford.Ful. ch. hi≈øt. B. 9, page 60. But none of the≈øe had been bi≈øhops of Wales. It is true the writ of Parker's con≈øecration, named Kitchen of Landaff for one. But it is equally true that he never appeared to a≈ø≈øi≈øt at the con≈øecration, and ≈øo it was performed without him by the four above named. Where then, I repeat it, will Mr. L. make out his ≈øucce≈ø≈øion, through the line of the old Briti≈øh bi≈øhops? If he was ≈øo unacquainted with hi≈øtory, as not to know that there was no manner of foundation for ≈øuch a pretence, he was unqualified to write upon the ≈øubject, and ought not to have meddled with it. If not, he has de≈øignedly impo≈øed upon his readers, and ought "to retract."

THE truth of the ca≈øe is, no hi≈øtory of the Briti≈øh church furni≈øhes the lea≈øt foundation, even of pretence, for ≈øuch a ≈øucce≈ø≈øion. Bi≈øhop Burnet ≈øays, that the reformers in England, expre≈ø≈øly allowed "that England received the faith from tho≈øe ≈øent from Rome by pope Gregory the great, i. e. Au≈øtin and his monks.Abridg. Vol. 1. page 103. And all the advocates for uninterrupted ≈øucce≈ø≈øion, I have ever ≈øeen, till Mr. L's book appeared, unanimou≈øly agree in tracing it up to Au≈øtin, and through him to St. Peter. Mr. Beach in particular, ≈øome years ago, in his controver≈øy with Mr. Hobart, ≈øays, "the pre≈øent arch-bi≈øhop of Canterbury is the ≈øeventy-third, who has fet in that ≈øee, ≈øince Au≈øtin the monk."Vind. page 7.
And tho' I don't imagine there is any great probability of an unbroken ≈øucce≈ø≈øion, even in that line, yet it mu≈øt be ≈øought there, or no where. 'Till therefore Mr. L. brings us ≈øome better authority for one, through the old Briti≈øh bi≈øhops, than his bare a≈ø≈øertion; he mu≈øt expect it will be treated with that contempt, ≈øuch a vi≈øionary enthu≈øia≈øtic ≈øcheme de≈øerves.

I CALL this notion of an uninterrupted ≈øucce≈ø≈øion, and the ab≈øolute nece≈ø≈øity of it to render go≈øpel admini≈øtration valid, a vi≈øionary enthu≈øia≈øtic ≈øcheme. It is ≈øo even when traced in any line. The evidence of the fact is ≈øo ≈ømall, and the probability, or rather evidence of an interruption, ≈øo great, that a man mu≈øt renounce the common principles of credibility, and act by an implicit faith, to give in to it, or at lea≈øt to lay any great weight upon it. But to be very confident of it, and that in a line where it is ab≈øolutely certain it is not to be found, argues, if po≈ø≈øible, a greater degree of weakne≈øs and credulity than what the mo≈øt vi≈øionary enthu≈øia≈øts are influenced by. And is not this even the ca≈øe with our author? For though he di≈øclaims a ≈øucce≈ø≈øion through the Romi≈øh church and lays the whole ≈øtre≈øs upon one thro' the old Briti≈øh bi≈øhops, which never had any exi≈øtence, ≈øave in a heated imagination, he is ≈øo confident of the truth of it, that he tells us, "we have as good evidence that their clergy derive their authority, by an uninterrupted ≈øucce≈ø≈øion from the apo≈øtles, (meaning thro' the line afore≈øaid) as we have of the de≈øcent of all mankind from Adam by ordinary generation."Page 26. The highe≈øt evidence to which, even Mr. Beach, pretended in this ca≈øe, and that in a line too, which bid much fairer, than the romantic one of our author, was only to put it upon a level, with that of the Levitical prie≈øthood in the family of Aaron. This indeed was much too high. But even this it
≈øeems will not content Mr. L. Nothing ≈øhort of one, equal to that "of our de≈øcent from Adam, will ≈øerve his turn." If the faith of the advocates of this doctrine, continues thus increa≈øing, we may expect it will ≈øoon grow up to full a≈ø≈øurance; and that the next ≈øtickler for uninterrupted ≈øucce≈ø≈øion, will put the evidence of it upon a par with that of our exi≈øtence.

LET us however, examine Mr. L's proof: And here let it be noted, that we have the mo≈øt clear and expre≈øs ≈øcriptural evidence of our natural de≈øcent from Adam, and therefore are ab≈øolutely certain of it.See Gen. i. 27, & ii. 22. Mal. ii. 15.10. Acts xvii. 26. The ≈øame he tells us, we have for the uninterrupted ≈øucce≈ø≈øion of their clergy from the apo≈øtles. Let it be al≈øo remembered, that this ≈øucce≈ø≈øion mu≈øt be in a line of bi≈øhops as ≈øuperior to pre≈øbyters, for he calls it "a regular ≈øucce≈ø≈øion of the epi≈øcopal power," "an apo≈øtolic ≈øucce≈ø≈øion," and "a ≈øucce≈ø≈øion of the go≈øpel mini≈øtry in the three orders." Barely a ≈øucce≈ø≈øion in the line of pre≈øbyters will not ≈øuffice. For we have ≈øuch a ≈øucce≈ø≈øion up to their bi≈øhops, and yet he denies us to be the mini≈øters of Chri≈øt. Now the argument by which he undertakes to prove his ≈øucce≈ø≈øion, is this. Chri≈øt's promi≈øe to his mini≈øters, contained in his commi≈ø≈øion, in Mat. xviii. 20, mu≈øt have failed unle≈øs there has been ≈øuch a ≈øucce≈ø≈øion as he pleads for, that is, in a direct line of bi≈øhops as a ≈øuperior order in the church. But why mu≈øt the promi≈øe have failed, unle≈øs there has been ≈øuch a ≈øucce≈ø≈øion? There is nothing in the commi≈ø≈øion, limiting the promi≈øe to ≈øuch a ≈øuperior order: Not the lea≈øt hint of the in≈øtitution of ≈øuch an order. The commi≈ø≈øion is but one, and therefore one order only is in≈øtituted by it. But if there were two, or ten, it would make no alteration: Since the promi≈øe is not limitted to any one in particular, a ≈øucce≈ø≈øion in either of them would an≈øwer all the ends of fulfilling
the promi≈øe. Mr. L. him≈øelf allows that this promi≈øe belongs to pre≈øbyters.Page 29. If ≈øo, then a continuation of the ≈øucce≈ø≈øion in the line of pre≈øbyters, would as effectually ≈øerve the accompli≈øhment of the promi≈øe, as one in the line of bi≈øhops: Con≈øequently, if it has been continued in the former, the promi≈øe is fully accompli≈øhed, even tho' it has been broken or interrupted in the latter; and therefore his argument from the promi≈øe, in ≈øupport of a ≈øucce≈ø≈øion in the line of bi≈øhops, is by his own confe≈ø≈øion, intirely defeated.

THE truth is, as the commi≈ø≈øion ≈øuppo≈øes but one order in the mini≈øtry, the utmo≈øt that can be argued from the annexed promi≈øe, in favour of a ≈øucce≈ø≈øion, even of any kind, is that there ≈øhall be a mini≈øtry continued in the church, to the end of time. How, or in what manner mini≈øters ≈øhall be introduced, whether in a regular unbroken fine of ≈øucce≈ø≈øion or not, whether by a ≈øuperior or inferior order of mini≈øters, yea whether by the officers of the church or the brethren, as the commi≈ø≈øion is wholly ≈øilent upon this head, ≈øo nothing relative thereto can be concluded from it. And although from other texts it appears, that it belongs, not to the private brethren, but to mini≈øters to ordain; yet for aught appearing in the commi≈ø≈øion it≈øelf, a ≈øucce≈ø≈øion of mini≈øters, even by lay ordination, would have as effectually ≈øecured the accompli≈øhment of the promi≈øe, as one by pre≈øbyters, yea or bi≈øhops them≈øelves.

THUS his bold a≈ø≈øertion "that we have the ≈øame evidence for the ≈øucce≈ø≈øion he pleads for, as we have for our de≈øcent from Adam, finally comes to this." For one we have the certain, indubitable, repeated, expre≈øs te≈øtimony of infallible ≈øcripture, which is evidence of the highe≈øt kind. For the other, we have only his forced interpretation of a particular text, which is no evidence at all.

BUT if ≈øcripture will not ≈øupport his confidence in this point, perhaps he thinks hi≈øtory will. div.head: SEC. VI. A indication of my di≈øcour≈øe upon pre≈øbyter an ordination, from the exceptions contained in Mr. L's book;‚Äîfrom page 27 to 38.

NOT to ≈øay any thing of Mr. L's logic, he ≈øeems to be well acquainted with a certain figure in rhetoric, by which a part is taken for the whole. Havi ‚Ä¢ gremarked upon one or two, among many, of Dr. Chauncy's arguments, he roundly tells us, "he has con≈øidered every thing material advanced by the Dr." The ≈øame method he takes, in his remarks upon me. Thus he begins them.‚Äî "The ≈øum of his argument is this, there is but one commi≈ø≈øion, and of con≈øequence can be but one order of go≈øpel mini≈øters." Page 27. Truly conci≈øe and laconic! An ea≈øy and compendious method this, of an≈øwering a book,‚Äîto remark upon one argument, out of many, and then pretend he has an≈øwered the whole; though perhaps not quite ≈øo ≈øafe and honourable to the author, unle≈øs he could be ≈øure, the pieces he pretends to an≈øwer, had never been ≈øeen by his readers. But if he had read my piece, he mu≈øt have ob≈øerved that I u≈øed ≈øundry others in ≈øupport of the doctrine I undertook to defend. I argued it, from pre≈øbyters being ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ce≈ø≈øors to the apo≈øtles in their ordinary „Äà‚óä„Äâ . From there being in fact but one order „Äà‚óä„Äâ to be found in the go≈øpel. From pre≈øbyters
being true ≈øcripture bi≈øhops, and the only hi≈øhops the go≈øpel owns. From expre≈øs in≈øtances of pre≈øbyterian ordination found in ≈øcripture. And finally, from the ≈øuffrage of antiquity,‚Äîthe unanimous judgment and practice of the reformed churches abroad,‚Äîthe fir≈øt reformers in England, and many great and learned epi≈øcopalians ≈øince.‚Äî How then could he pretend, "that this was the ≈øum of what I had advanced, in ≈øupport of my principles?" However, ≈øince he choo≈øes to combat only this one argument, I ≈øhall follow him in his remarks upon it. His words are, Mr. Welles ≈øays, page 17, the≈øe la≈øt words (meaning the promi≈øe annexed to the commi≈ø≈øion) plainly ≈øhew that this promi≈øe was made, not to the per≈øons of the apo≈øtles, but to their office as mini≈øters in Chri≈øt's church; and con≈øequently that their office is to continue to the end of the world.‚Äî He a≈ø≈øerts, page 16, this is the commi≈ø≈øion, and the only commi≈ø≈øion we have any account of,‚Äîwhich Chri≈øt gave to his apo≈øtles. The con≈øequence of which Mr. E. ≈øays, mu≈øt be this,‚Äî "that the commi≈ø≈øion con≈øtituted them apo≈øtles, and therefore the apo≈øtolic office mu≈øt continue to the end of time." Page 28.

ANSWER.‚ÄîIf by apo≈øtolic office, he means the office the apo≈øtles ≈øu≈øtained, as ordinary mini≈øters in the church; I readily grant that the commi≈ø≈øion in Mat. xxviii. did con≈øtitute them apo≈øtles, and that their office, in this ≈øen≈øe of it, is to continue to the end of the world. But if by apo≈øtolic office, he means their office as apo≈øtles, properly ≈øo called, con≈øidered in their extraordinary character, I deny that it was to be continued, and affirm there is nothing in the words he pretends to quote from me, that will infer ≈øuch a conclu≈øion. commi≈ø≈øion, was made, not to the per≈øons of the apo≈øtles, but to their office." But as what? Not as apo≈øtles, but as I there expre≈øs it, "as mini≈øters in Chri≈øt's church," i e. ≈øtanding ordinary mini≈øters. BUT, ≈øays Mr. L. "the con≈øequence (meaning from my words) is plainly this; that the commi≈ø≈øion con≈øtituted them apo≈øtles, or el≈øe that they acted as apo≈øtles without any commi≈ø≈øion."

I ANSWER:‚ÄîThis is by no means a plain con≈øequence neither. Had I ≈øaid, as he has imperfectly quoted me, "that this is the only commi≈ø≈øion we have any account of, that Chri≈øt gave his apo≈øtles," and had added nothing further, it would indeed have followed, not as he ≈øays, "that they acted without any commi≈ø≈øion;" but that, for aught appeared in ≈øcripture, they acted without any. The≈øe two conclu≈øions are very different.‚Äî The ≈øcripture gives no account of the ordination of Silas, Apollos, Epaphroditus, &c. I tru≈øt, however, he him≈øelf will not from hence conclude that

For altho' as ≈øtanding ordinary mini≈øters, they had no other commi≈ø≈øion, yet they might have as apo≈øtles. It was in the former view I ≈øpake of them, not in the latter. Certainly they were called apo≈øtles long before this commi≈ø≈øion was given, even upon their being called by Chri≈øt.Mat. x. 2. The commi≈ø≈øion of the apo≈øtles as ≈øuch, as extraordinary officers, was in an extraordinary way; by an immediate call from heaven. When it was they received this commi≈ø≈øion, whether upon their fir≈øt call, as ≈øome ≈øuppo≈øe, or at the day of Pentico≈øt, as others think, is perhaps difficult certainly to determine. But as ≈øtanding ordinary mini≈øters, they were to have ≈øucce≈ø≈øors to the end of time; and therefore it was nece≈ø≈øary their commi≈ø≈øion, in this character, ≈øhould be particularly recorded; for this concerned

Accordingly we find, this commi≈ø≈øion is in fact recorded: 'Tis that we have been con≈øidering: 'Tis that to which the promi≈øe is annexed of Chri≈øt's pre≈øence to the end of the world; and the ≈øame concerning which I a≈ø≈øerted in my ≈øermon, "that it is the only one, we have any account of, which Chri≈øt gave to his apo≈øtles, in virtue of which they were improved to act as ordinary mini≈øters in his church." OUR author's next remark is to this purpo≈øe,‚Äî that while I am proving from one commi≈ø≈øion, that one order only of mini≈øters can be virtuated by it, I my≈øelf, in effect, allow two, and ≈øo defeat my own argument: For he ≈øays, I call the apo≈øtles in one place, extraordinary officers, and in another, ordinary ones, and yet the≈øe are both impowered by one commi≈ø≈øion; hence he concludes that I am "refuted by my≈øelf."Page 28, 29.

I ANSWER, had he hone≈øtly cited the pa≈ø≈øage he pretended to quote from me, the weakne≈øs of this conclu≈øion of his would have been obvious at fir≈øt view. I HAD ≈øaid in my ≈øermon, "that the apo≈øtles in their extraordinary character, had no ≈øucce≈ø≈øors." This Mr. L. calls "a bold a≈ø≈øertion," and demands "what evidence I had produced to ≈øupport it."Page 29.

ANSWER. As the a≈ø≈øertion is a negative, had no evidence been produced, it would hardly have de≈øerved the epithet of "bold." As this extraordinary character of the apo≈øtles had its ri≈øe in the extraordinary circum≈øtances, attending them, and was founded in the extraordinary powers be≈øtowed upon them, it mu≈øt nece≈ø≈øarily have cea≈øed, if the circum≈øtances and powers have cea≈øed, on which it was founded; but that the latter have cea≈øed, Mr. L. will not deny: For whatever powers they

they met him at Miletus; and in full po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of it, he left them, when he took his final leave of them, never to ≈øee them more. Judge then, who is to be credited in this ca≈øe; our author, who ≈øays the≈øe elders were only ≈øimple pre≈øbyters, without any pa≈øtoral authority in this church; or the apo≈øtle, who expre≈ø≈øly charges them, to exerci≈øe ≈øuch authority in the government of it!‚ÄîMr. L. who confidently a≈ø≈øerts, that Timothy was their only bi≈øhop, to whom they and the church of Ephe≈øus were ≈øubjected, as their ≈øingle pa≈øtor or over≈øeer; or St. Paul, who a≈ø≈øures us, that the≈øe were appointed by the Holy Gho≈øt, in parity, the over≈øeers or bi≈øhops of this whole flock!‚Äî"Look into the ≈øcriptures. Judge for your≈øelves. If what I have advanced, is not fact, it may be ea≈øily expo≈øed. If it is an undeniable truth, it is a truth of great importance, if religion be ≈øo."
I AM now prepared for a few remarks upon ≈øome ≈øelect pa≈ø≈øages in this part of Mr. L's defence, which will conclude this ≈øection.
HE enquires,‚Äî"If the elders of Ephe≈øus had power to ordain and govern, what need of ≈øending Timothy there?"Page 43. leaving him there, he ≈øhould have ≈øaid.‚ÄîI an≈øwer,‚Äî

IT does not appear from ≈øcripture, that this church had any ≈øettled pa≈øtors at this time. But if it had, they needed the divine directions concerning ordination and government, contained in the≈øe epi≈øtles to Timothy, as much as we do at this day. And who more proper to receive, and put them in execution, than an evangeli≈øt, an extraordinary officer, and a faithful companion of Paul? But till he can prove that Timothy was le≈øt there, as a re≈øident pa≈øtor over that church, as fully as I have, that the elders were, this will be no ≈øervice to his cau≈øe. Barely his being ≈øent to Ephe≈øus, will not prove this. If ≈øo, Tychicus al≈øo was their
