And upon the ≈øame principle, Timothy mu≈øt have been bi≈øhop al≈øo of Corinth, The≈ø≈øalonica, Macedonia, &c. for to all the≈øe was he ≈øent as well as to Ephe≈øus. This would be to make him a prelati≈øt as well as a non-re≈øident, and exhibit a compleat idea of modern epi≈øcopacy.‚ÄîAgain,‚Äî
HE demands a proof from facts recorded in ≈øcripture, "that mere pre≈øbyters, in virtue of their office as ≈øuch, did ordain officers in the church of Chri≈øt."Page 46, 47.‚ÄîAn≈øwer.

IF by mere pre≈øbyters, he means, ≈øuch as tho≈øe in his church, profe≈ø≈øedly ≈øubjecting them≈øelves to bi≈øhops, and di≈øclaiming all pa≈øtoral authority in ordination and government; none will pretend to prove from ≈øcripture that ≈øuch ever did ordain.‚ÄîAnd good rea≈øon for it. The ≈øcripture knows of no ≈øuch order. But if he means ≈øcripture-pre≈øbyters, ≈øuch as tho≈øe at Ephe≈øus; pre≈øbyter-bi≈øhops, ≈øuch as Timothy and Titus were directed to ordain; I have already proved, ≈øuch pre≈øbyters did in fact ordain, and that by virtue of their office. Of this ≈øort were tho≈øe, who ordained Paul, Barnabas and Timothy, as I have already proved, by expre≈øs facts recorded in ≈øcripture. And what is more:‚ÄîThe ≈øcriptures plainly ≈øhew, that none but ≈øuch ought to ordain; they being the only mini≈øters, authorized by Chri≈øt's general commi≈ø≈øion, and ve≈øted with all the powers it contains.

WHAT he quotes from Mr. Beach, re≈øpecting our fir≈øt mini≈øters, who were ordained by the Engli≈øh bi≈øhops, is no valid objection again≈øt this, even allowing that there was no expre≈ø≈øed intention, either in the ordainers, or ordained, of conveying the power of ordination. For the commi≈ø≈øion of Chri≈øt, not the intention of the ordainers, is what conveys the power in ordination, as I ≈øhewed in my ≈øermon. I now add:‚ÄîThe≈øe fir≈øt

Either therefore he is no mini≈øter of Chri≈øt, not being ve≈øted with his commi≈ø≈øion in ordination: Or if the words u≈øed in his ordination, were ≈øufficiently expre≈ø≈øive of ≈øuch inve≈øtiture, in his ca≈øe; they were equally ≈øo in that of our mini≈øters; con≈øequently, they were cloathed with all the powers the commi≈ø≈øion contains, of which that of ordination is confe≈ø≈øedly one.

As to the other part of this objection, the oath of canonical obedience; though it is far from being true, that this, as he affirms, includes in it "a ≈øolemn promi≈øe never to ordain others;" yet allowing it did, ≈øuch promi≈øe, being evidently ≈øinful, can't be binding upon con≈øcience, but is ip≈øo facto null and void. A number of the Jews bound them≈øelves by ≈øolemn oath, "not to eat or drink till they had killed Paul."Acts xxiii. 12. If this oath was binding, it was their duty to keep it; con≈øequently, murder is a duty. For the murder of Paul or of them≈øelves, was a nece≈ø≈øary con≈øequence of their keeping this oath. But if it was not binding in this in≈øtance, no more was it in the ca≈øe he ≈øuppo≈øes, con≈øequently the objection is of no force.

MR. L. ≈øays,‚Äî"Nothing is now claimed by our bi≈øhops, but the very ≈øame that St. Paul gave in charge to Timothy. Nothing prohibited to the elders and pre≈øbyters of our church, that he commanded the elders to do, at Ephe≈øus."Page 47, 48. Is this really the ca≈øe? Does he not expre≈ø≈øly command, "let the elders who rule well be accounted worthy of double honour?"Chap. v. ver. 15. But what occa≈øion for this, if the bi≈øhop had the ≈øole power of government? I add; where does he find the apo≈øtle charging his grace, Timothy lord bi≈øhop of Ephe≈øus, "to entangle him≈øelf with the affairs of this life:"2 Tim. ii. 4. To intermeddle, and bear a chief part in civil matters, to erect courts, and pre≈øide in them, either in per≈øon, or by his lay chancellor, for the trial of all cau≈øes, te≈øtamentary and matrimonial, &c. &c. &c.? And yet he knows a ≈øet of bi≈øhops, pretending to be the only ≈øucce≈ø≈øors of Timothy and the apo≈øtles, who actually claim and exerci≈øe all the fore-mentioned powers. Paul tells the Ephe≈øian elders, "that the Holy Gho≈øt had made them pa≈øtors or bi≈øhops over the whole flock," and charges them to exerci≈øe the powers of ≈øuch, to feed, to rule and govern this church as its proper bi≈øhops, to u≈øe their authority, if nece≈ø≈øary, in a way of di≈øcipline, and prevent fal≈øe teachers creeping in, to draw away di≈øciples: And is there any thing, I a≈øk, of this kind, allowed to Mr. L. and his brother-pre≈øbyters in their church? Not in the lea≈øt. He him≈øelf knows, that by the rules and canons of his order, he is ab≈øolutely prohibited every thing of this kind.

THUS have I an≈øwered every thing material in this part of our author's defence;‚Äîparticularly ≈øhewed, from facts recorded in ≈øcripture, that Timothy neither was, nor could be a fixed bi≈øhop of Ephe≈øus, ≈øettled there, with governing powers over the≈øe elders; but that this church was mo≈øt

I HAVE nothing to add, but my mo≈øt earne≈øt wi≈øh and prayer, that the great head of the church would guide us into all truth, and in≈øpire all prote≈øtants, e≈øpecially go≈øpel mini≈øters, with the ≈øpirit of meekne≈øs, forbearance and charity towards each other, even though not exactly of one mind in all points; that ≈øo, in≈øtead of worrying and cruelly condemning our fellow chri≈øtians, and thereby, giving advantage again≈øt us to the patrons of Popery, infidelity and irreligion; we may all cordially unite, in oppo≈øing the common enemies of chri≈øtianity, and promoting the grand and important truths, in which we all agree.

div.head: SEC. VIII. Mr. L's proof of epi≈øcopacy from the writings of the fathers, contained in his appendix,‚Äîfrom page 49 to 61, examined and refuted.
div.p: OUR author propo≈øes, in this part of his work, "to enquire what form of government prevailed, immediately after the apo≈øtles." "To an≈øwer this enquiry, he tells us, he will exhibit a few extracts, from the ancient fathers."

HIS fir≈øt extract is, from that truly ancient apo≈øtolic father, arch-deacon Echard of England, who flouri≈øhed about A. D. 1699. But what purpo≈øe this extract is de≈øigned to ≈øerve, the reader mu≈øt determine for him≈øelf, for I am not able to help him.

HIS next is from Eu≈øebius. He, I own, is one of the fathers; but far from being an ancient one: For he lived in the fourth century. And as he him≈øelf tells us, in his hi≈øtory, "that he could trace no foot≈øteps of any going before him, only in a few narratives,"Lib. I. cap. 1. there is little dependence upon what he ≈øays, of things ≈øo remote from his time. However, the pa≈ø≈øage quoted is this:‚Äî"St. John, being by Domitian's death, relea≈øed from bani≈øhment, returned, and took the care of the church of Ephe≈øus; and upon the invitation of the neighbouring churches, who had enjoyed only the mini≈øtry of pre≈øbyters and deacons, he went to them, and con≈øecrated bi≈øhops," &c.Mr. L's def. page 49, 50. I have carefully examined the pa≈ø≈øage in Eu≈øebius, Mr. L. refers to; but find it very different from what he has quoted. None of the words, ≈øet down in italics, are to be found in the original. The pa≈ø≈øage truly rendered, is as follows. Speaking of John, he ≈øays,‚Äî"After the tyrant's death, he returned to Ephe≈øus; and being invited ≈øo to do, went al≈øo among the neighbouring nations, where he appointed bi≈øhops, e≈øtabli≈øhed regular and compleat churches, electing to the clerical office whom≈øoever the Holy Gho≈øt pointed out for the ≈øame."Eu≈øeb. eccl. hi≈øt. Lib. III. cap. 23. Though I will not charge Mr. L. with di≈øhone≈øty, in thus pretending to quote from Eu≈øebius, what is not to be found in him; ≈øince 'tis po≈ø≈øible he might not have lei≈øure to con≈øult the original, but taking the tran≈ølation upon tru≈øt, ≈øet down the pa≈ø≈øage as he found it, in ≈øome epi≈øcopal writer; yet every one mu≈øt ≈øee, the words added, in Mr. L's
quotation, intirely alter the ≈øen≈øe of the pa≈ø≈øage, and make it evident it was done, by ≈øomebody, to favor epi≈øcopacy, and impo≈øe upon the unlearned reader. With the addition of the words,‚Äî"who had enjoyed only the mini≈øtry of pre≈øbyters and deacons;" the pa≈ø≈øage does indeed ≈øeem to favour the doctrine of three orders in the mini≈øtry; but let it be read without this corrupt addition, and then let the intelligent reader judge, what it is to Mr. L's purpo≈øe; or whether any other eight lines, taken at random, from Eu≈øebius, or any other author, will not as effectually prove epi≈øcopacy, as the≈øe here quoted? Stripped of this addition, the pa≈ø≈øage mentions but one officer, viz. a bi≈øhop in the≈øe churches; and as that, in ≈øcripture, means the ≈øame as pre≈øbyter, by his own conce≈ø≈øion, it can be nothing to his purpo≈øe.

HIS next quotation is from Irenaeus,‚Äî"That Polycarp was con≈øtituted by the apo≈øtles in A≈øia, bi≈øhop of the church at Smyrna." An≈øwer:‚ÄîSt. Paul, who≈øe authority is at lea≈øt equal to that of Irenaeus, tells us, "that the Holy Gho≈øt con≈øtituted the elders of Ephe≈øus, bi≈øhops of the church of Ephe≈øus." If therefore Polycarp's being calle I bi≈øhop, proves him ≈øuch in Mr. L's ≈øen≈øe of the word; the≈øe elders mu≈øt be ≈øo too. But then what becomes of his main argument for prelacy, from Timothy's being bi≈øhop of Ephe≈øus? Or if he ≈øtill denies the≈øe elders to be bi≈øhops, though they are called ≈øo, the ≈øame he mu≈øt do as to Polycarp's. And ≈øo this extract fails him al≈øo.

BUT he tells us, the de≈øign of Irenaeus was to prove a ≈øucce≈ø≈øion of apo≈øtolic doctrines, "but his argument is equally good in favor of a ≈øucce≈ø≈øion of bi≈øhops." And this, he ≈øays, will prove "that bi≈øhops were ≈øuperior to pre≈øbyters." An≈øwer:‚ÄîNot till he proves there were, be≈øides the≈øe here called bi≈øhops, any pre≈øbyters in that church for them "to be ≈øuperior to." Irenaeus, in
the pa≈ø≈øage quoted, mentions but one order only. This extract therefore, is ≈øo far from helping Mr. L's ≈øcheme of three orders, that it is wholly in favour of our's which has but one.

THE ≈øame an≈øwer al≈øo will ≈øerve, for his three next extracts from Irenaeus. Hi≈øt. lib. v. cap. 6.

HIS next extract is from Jerom,‚Äî"Quid facit except√° ordinatione, epi≈øcopus, quod pre≈øbyter non facit?" "What can a bi≈øhop do, except ordination, that a pre≈øbyter may not do? Certainly there is Mr. L's bi≈øhop can confirm, hold ≈øpiritual courts, exerci≈øe di≈øcipline, &c. But is a pre≈øbyter allowed to do tho≈øe? Nothing le≈øs. But Jerom does not even in≈øinuate, that ordination belongs only to the bi≈øhop, by divine right. And had Mr. L. read the epi≈øtle, from whence the≈øe words are taken, he mu≈øt have ≈øeen, that the whole ≈øcope of it is to

When therefore he u≈øes the words Mr. L. has quoted, he evidently does it to ≈øhew "what was the practice of the church in his time;" not what prevailed in that of the apo≈øtles. 'Tis pity Mr. L. will not be at the pains of reading the fathers him≈øelf. It might, perhaps, ≈øave his friends many a blu≈øh upon his account.

THE next church he mentions, as upon the epi≈øcopal model, is that of Antioch. "In this, he tells us, was a number of believers, whom the apo≈øtles, Paul, and Barnabas, "took the government of for ≈øome time." Strange! Two bi≈øhops in one church at once! How different the modern epi≈øcopacy from the ancient! Formerly one church could boa≈øt two bi≈øhops, and both apo≈øtles. But their ≈øucce≈ø≈øors, it ≈øeems, have made ≈øuch improvement in the prelatic art, that one bi≈øhop now will ≈øerve for more than an hundred. This mu≈øt be ancient epi≈øcopacy inverted. However, this was not the ca≈øe long. "Paul and Barnabas, he ≈øays, were ≈øoon ≈øucceeded by Peter." What, Peter bi≈øhop of Antioch! We tho't he had been metropolitan of Rome. But this was not long. "Euodius ≈øoon takes his place; to whom ≈øucceeded Ignatius;" who≈øe epi≈øtles, we are told, contain the very model and marrow of modern epi≈øcopacy. Accordingly our author is longer upon this favourite patron, than all the re≈øt of the fathers; though I
think he gives us but one or two extracts from him, and them but ≈øhort.Page 52, 53.54, 55, 56.

As to the epi≈øtles a≈øcribed to Ignatius, Mr. L. mu≈øt know, if he has read Dr. Chauncy's ≈øermon, that they lie under very ≈øtrong ≈øu≈øpicions of forgery, or at lea≈øt of great adulteration and corruption. This the Dr. largely ≈øhews in his appendix, and offers ≈øuch arguments in ≈øupport of the charge, as makes it, at lea≈øt very highly probable, if not certain this was the ca≈øe. The≈øe, Mr. L. does not attempt to an≈øwer. He indeed tells us, "that bi≈øhops Beveridge and Pear≈øon have fully confuted, Me≈ø≈ørs. Daille, L'arroque, and all others, in whatever they have advanced again≈øt the≈øe epi≈øtles."‚ÄîAnd I can tell him "that L'arroque undertook to an≈øwer Beveridge and Pear≈øon, as appears by a manu≈øcript found among his papers, in which he had made great progre≈øs; but at the de≈øire of ≈øeveral per≈øons, who leaned too much to be epi≈øcopal cau≈øe, he did not fini≈øh this reply."Nov. Rep. Lit. Tout. l. Art. 5, p. 56, 57. A victory obtained by ≈øuch arts as the≈øe, can do no great honour to the conquerors. This ≈øtory, Mr. L. if he plea≈øes, may confront with his, concerning Bl ‚Ä¢ ndel in page 69 of his book.

BUT if we ≈øhould allow the≈øe epi≈øtles to be genuine, they will really make nothing in favour of dioce≈øan epi≈øcopacy, but much again≈øt it. 'Tis true, they frequently mention bi≈øhops, pre≈øbyters, and deacons: But then it is equally true, that the bi≈øhop de≈øcribed in the≈øe, was e≈ø≈øentially different from the dioce≈øan one. The "Ignatian bi≈øhop" pre≈øided over but one ≈øingle church, was therefore no more than a congregational bi≈øhop, or pa≈øtor of a particular church: Whereas the dioce≈øan one, pre≈øides over many ≈øcores or hundreds of congregations. Again,‚Äîthe former had much the ≈øame authority over his pre≈øbyters, as the rector
of a pari≈øh, in the church of England, has over his a≈ø≈øi≈øtant curates, who are not pretended to be of a different order, but have radically the ≈øame power with the rector: But the church of England bi≈øhop, is a≈ø≈øerted to be a different order from the pre≈øbyter; by divine right, ≈øuperior to him, and ve≈øted with the ≈øole power of ordination and government. A few extracts from the≈øe epi≈øtles will ≈øerve to prove this. "Let all follow the bi≈øhop as Je≈øus Chri≈øt; and the pre≈øbyters, as the apo≈øtles."‚Äî"Let none do any of tho≈øe things which belong to the church without the bi≈øhop."‚Äî"Where the bi≈øhop appears, let the multitude, or congregation be."Ignat. Epi≈øt. ad Smyrn. ≈øec. 8, page 37. "If the prayer of one or two have ≈øo much efficacy, how much more the prayer of the bi≈øhop, and the whole church? "Do nothing without the bi≈øhop and pre≈øbyters, but when you meet together, let there be one prayer, &c. run all together as to one temple of God, as to one altar."Ad Magne≈ø. ≈øec. 7. "Where the pa≈øtor is, there do you, as ≈øheep follow."Epi≈øt. ad Philadelph. ≈øec. 2. From the≈øe pa≈ø≈øages it appears, that the dioce≈øe of the Ignatian bi≈øhop, was no larger, than could meet together in one place, for public wor≈øhip, with the bi≈øhop and pre≈øbyters. But it is impo≈ø≈øible for a modern dioce≈øe, con≈øi≈øting of ≈øome hundreds of congregations, to attend divine ≈øervice in one place.

AGAIN:‚ÄîIt is plain, from the≈øe epi≈øtles, that the ≈øacraments were not to be admini≈øtered, but in the pre≈øence of the bi≈øhop. "Let that euchari≈øt be accounted valid which is celebrated in the bi≈øhop's pre≈øence, or by his permi≈ø≈øion; where the bi≈øhop appears, let the multitude be;‚Äîit is not lawful without the bi≈øhop, either to baptize or to
make a love fea≈øt."Ad Smyrn. ≈øec. 8, p. 37. "Take care to u≈øe, or frequent, one euchari≈øt; for there is one fle≈øh of our Lord Je≈øus Chri≈øt, and one cup for union in his blood; there is one altar, as there is one bi≈øhop."Ad Philadelph. ≈øec. 4. "Since every one of you by name, with common con≈øent, meet together,‚Äîthat you may obey your bi≈øhop and the pre≈øbytery, with an undivided mind, breaking one loaf, which is the medicine of immortality."Ad Ephe≈ø. ≈øec. 20. From the≈øe pa≈ø≈øages it appears, that as every altar, or communion table, had its bi≈øhop; ≈øo all the communicants, in his whole dioce≈øe, ≈øteadily met together with the bi≈øhop, to receive the ≈øacraments, and that it was not allowed to receive them, but from his hand, or in his pre≈øence. But now, how different is the ca≈øe from this in the church of England? There, one bi≈øhop has many ≈øcores or hundreds of communion tables in his dioce≈øe, and a great many thou≈øand communicants; for whom it would be ab≈øolutely impo≈ø≈øible, to attend the communion at one table, with their bi≈øhop, and receive the con≈øecrated elements, at his hands, or in his pre≈øence.

B. 2, p. 109.

IN the mean time, I am at a lo≈øs to know what he means by ≈øaying,‚Äî"that pre≈øbytery was introduced into Scotland, at the time of the reformation, by rebellion," unle≈øs he thinks it mu≈øt needs be rebellion, for ≈øubjects to be chri≈øtians or prote≈øtants, who are ≈øo unhappy, as to have a pagan or papi≈øt for their prince: But if ≈øo the greate≈øt part of the Engli≈øh nation, epi≈øcopalians not excepted, were guilty of rebellion, at the glorious revolution. OUR author ≈øeems to blame me for ≈øaying,‚Äî"there has never been any pretence for lay-ordination in the church of Scotland." "This he ≈øays, may be true, and it may not. If John Knox never was lawfully ordained, the Scotch ordinations are no better than tho≈øe in N. England." "This, he ≈øays, he ≈øuppo≈øes, to be the ca≈øe." But I mu≈øt tell him, the good king Edward ≈øuppo≈øed otherwi≈øe,
or he never would, 'tis pre≈øumed, have improved Mr. Knox as his own chaplain, and offered him a bi≈øhoprick, as it is certain he did.Pierce's vind. p. 36, Full. ch. hi≈øt. B. 9, p. 6.

MR. L. ≈øeems to be ≈øure that epi≈øcopacy was the original con≈øtitution in England. If it was, I am ≈øure nothing he has ≈øaid proves it to be ≈øo.‚Äî The authorities he has brought are by no means ≈øufficient for the purpo≈øe. In the fir≈øt place, they a≈ø≈øert no ≈øuch thing in the quotations he has made from them. Be≈øides, they are te≈øtimonies ≈øome ten or twelve hundred years too late, to be depended upon, as authentic vouchers in this ca≈øe. If St. Paul planted chri≈øtianity in England, as many ≈øuppo≈øe, 'tis natural to ≈øuppo≈øe that he would ≈øettle the ≈øame form of ordination, he him≈øelf had received, and this has been proved to be pre≈øbyterian.

HAVING thus attended our author, in his ≈øearch after epi≈øcopacy among the writings of the fathers, having particularly examined all his extracts, from them, and exhibited a number more from the ≈øame writings, in ≈øupport of the contrary opinion; I now freely ≈øubmit the whole‚Äî"to the cool and candid" to determine whether they are of ≈øo much "weight in his favor" as he ≈øeems to "per≈øuade" him≈øelf they are. UPON quitting his favorite Ignatius, he has the≈øe words,‚Äî"But is not this fact evident and undeniable, from the forecited pa≈ø≈øages, that in the next age after the apo≈øtles, epi≈øcopacy was univer≈øally received, in all the churches of Chri≈øt?"Page 53, 54. Be≈øides the≈øe, Mr. L. had, as yet, brought no te≈øtimonies from any writer, within two hundred years after Chri≈øt, except from Irenaeus only; and the≈øe barely ≈øome ≈øcraps, detached from their connection, and which even then, favour his cau≈øe in ≈øound only, not in ≈øen≈øe; as has, I tru≈øt ≈øufficiently appeared, from the foregoing remarks. And yet this is the whole evidence, on which he affirms it "to be undeniable fact, that epi≈øcopacy, in his ≈øen≈øe of the word, was univer≈øally received, in all the churches of Chri≈øt." What may not one make to be fact, and undeniably ≈øo, upon ≈øuch evidence as this? Much to be pitied is the man, who is ≈øo far under the government of prejudice, as to imagine ≈øuch evidence as this undeniable! HE goes on:‚Äî"Though this ≈øtrangely ≈ølipt Dr. Chauncy's ob≈øervation, when he read the fathers, yet I ≈øuppo≈øe their te≈øtimony may be of ≈øome weight, with tho≈øe who≈øe ob≈øervation this point has not ≈ølipt."Page 54.

ANSWER:‚ÄîDr. Chauncy never ≈øo much as hinted that this fact had ≈ølipt his ob≈øervation. He well knew that no ≈øuch fact ever took place within that team of time, and ≈øo mu≈øt every one el≈øe, who impartially reads the fathers. What the Dr. referred to, when he ≈øaid, "unle≈øs it had ≈ølipt his ob≈øervation," was this, "that the mode of diction," "bi≈øhops, pre≈øbyters, and deacons," was ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ t to be met with, till he come to Clement of Alexandria, who flouri≈øhed towards the clo≈øe of the ≈øecond century. If Mr. L. will be plea≈øed to point out an in≈øtance, the Dr. no doubt, will readily own "it ≈ølipt his ob≈øervation." 'Till then, he will have ju≈øt occa≈øion for blu≈øhing, whenever ‚Ä¢ e reflects, how gro≈ø≈øly he has perverted the Dr's words.

MR. L. ≈øays, "he is ≈øurprized that the Dr. ≈øhould deny, that the ancients con≈øtantly a≈ø≈øert the government of the church, to have been epi≈øcopal all along from the times of the apo≈øtles, without producing a ≈øentence from one of the fathers, to ≈øupport his denial."Page 60.

ONE would think, a man who engages in a public controver≈øy, ought to be ≈øo well acquainted with the rules of di≈øputation, as to know, that it belongs to tho≈øe who affirm a fact, to bring evidence in proof of it; not to tho≈øe who deny it.‚Äî This was the ca≈øe here. Dr. Hoadly affirmed a certain fact to be declared in the fathers. Dr. Chauncy denies they mention any ≈øuch fact. This he has a right to do, without proving ≈øuch denial. The proof lay upon the affirmer. It lies upon all the advocates of epi≈øcopacy in this in≈øtance. It has often been called for:‚ÄîBut the call has never yet been an≈øwered, by producing ≈øo much as a ≈øingle pa≈ø≈øage, within two hundred years after Chri≈øt, except from the ju≈øtly di≈øputed epi≈øtles of
Ignatius, wherein this fact is affirmed, either in direct terms, or in words from whence it can be fairly deduced. 'Till this is done, Dr. Chauncy, and all mankind have a right to deny the fact.‚Äî Had Mr. L. thought of this, it might have ≈øaved him his great "≈øurprize."

HE adds:‚Äî"In≈øtead of ≈øupporting this denial from the fathers, the Dr. has quoted the opinion of the moderns." Page 60. Mr. L. is quite mi≈øtaken in the de≈øign of the≈øe quotations. They were bro't only to ≈øhew, that in the ages po≈øterior to the ≈øecond century, and even after the e≈øtabli≈øhment of epi≈øcopacy, it was far from being indubitably clear, that this e≈øtabli≈øhment, and the practice upon it, had taken place upon the foot of a divine right.‚Äî And in this view there are none, I imagine, ≈øave Mr. L. and his party, but what will think them pertinent and conclu≈øive.

IN an≈øwer to the Dr's demand "of an example of epi≈øcopal ordination within the two fir≈øt centuries," Mr. L. in≈øtances in the ordination of Titus by St. Paul." Page 61. But pray how came he by the knowledge that Paul ordained Titus? He affirms it, and that is all. If he had any proof, why did he not produce it? Sure I am, the ≈øcripture affords him none. But if it did, how will this prove he did it in the capacity of a bi≈øhop? Paul him≈øelf was ordained by pre≈øbyters: No doubt then he acted as a pre≈øbyter in ordaining Titus, if he acted at all. "But, ≈øays he, that Titus had epi≈øcopal ordination, appears from his being left in Crete to ≈øet in order the things that were wanting," &c.

ANSWER:‚ÄîThe≈øe directions given to Titus, no more prove him to be bi≈øhop of Crete, i. e. of a ≈øuperior order to the elders he was to ordain; than like directions given to Peter, prove him to be ≈øuperior to the other apo≈øtles. Be≈øides, tho≈øe
whom he was to ordain, are expre≈ø≈øly called bi≈øhops. Tit. i. 7.‚Äî"That thou maye≈øt ordain elders, ≈øays the apo≈øtle. He means bi≈øhops. In every city, ≈øays he, for he would not have the whole I≈øland committed to one man; but that every one ≈øhould have and mind his own proper cure; for ≈øo, he knew the labor would be ea≈øier to him, and the people to be governed, would have more care taken of them; ≈øince their teacher would not run about to govern many churches, but would attend to the ruling of one only, and ≈øo would keep it in good order." He him≈øelf was no more, therefore could not be their ≈øuperior, con≈øequently not their bi≈øhop, in Mr. L's ≈øen≈øe of the word. And from Jerom it appears, that he whom they called bi≈øhop, in the church of Alexandria, was cho≈øen from among, and ≈øet apart to his epi≈øcopal office by his pre≈øbyters of that church, for two hundred years, in the beginning of it.

AN example of epi≈øcopal ordination, not from ≈øcripture, but from the fathers of the two fir≈øt centuries, was what was demanded. Mr. L. ≈øays he could produce many. Why has he not then done it? Was it for want of inclination, or ability?‚Äî Doubtle≈øs the latter. Thus after all his boa≈øted appeal to the fathers, they afford him as little relief, as the ≈øcriptures do.

div.head: SEC. IX. Examination of Mr. L's appeal to the fir≈øt reformers for his divine right of epi≈øcopacy,‚Äîfrom page 61 to 65.
div.p: IN both the pieces Mr. L. undertook to an≈øwer, it was ob≈øerved, that this doctrine "of the unalterable divine right of epi≈øcopacy," was a ≈øtranger to the fir≈øt reformers, even in the church of England. This was done with a view to expo≈øe the bigotry of tho≈øe anathematizing zealots, the modern ≈øons of that church, who, like Mr. L. unchurch and unchri≈øtianize all the prote≈øtant world but them≈øelves. Sundry te≈øtimonies were adduced, from the fir≈øt reformers and latter writers of the church of England, both bi≈øhops and others, to prove that this was not the doctrine of that church, at the time of the reformation, and many years after.‚ÄîThat though for rea≈øons of ≈øtate, they concurred with the epi≈øcopal ≈øettlement in England; yet they did not look upon it to be of divine right, or ≈øo e≈ø≈øential as to nullify all ordinations, unle≈øs tho≈øe performed by bi≈øhops, in their ≈øen≈øe of the word. And it was particularly ≈øhewed, that the fir≈øt who publicly maintained that uncharitable anti-chri≈øtian doctrine, was the famous arch-bi≈øhop Laud, of papi≈øtical and per≈øecuting memory; and that he was publicly rebuked by his ≈øuperior for ≈øo doing.
MR. L. declares him≈øelf of the ≈øame principles, and undertakes to defend them, by an appeal to the fir≈øt reformers. Let us examine his proofs.

HIS fir≈øt is from arch-bi≈øhop Cranmer, in the≈øe
words, "We read not that any, not being a bi≈øhop, hath, ≈øince the beginning of Chri≈øt's church, ordained a prie≈øt." If by bi≈øhop, is here meant a congregational bi≈øhop, all pre≈øbyterians will agree, that none but ≈øuch have power to ordain: But then it will be nothing to Mr. L's purpo≈øe.‚ÄîBut if a dioce≈øan bi≈øhop is intended, then all that Cranmer can be ≈øuppo≈øed to mean is, that the bu≈øine≈øs of ordaining has been confined to ≈øuch bi≈øhops, not as ≈øolely ve≈øted with that power by the law of Chri≈øt; but only by human appointment, and the cu≈øtom of the church. For bi≈øhop Burnet a≈ø≈øures us, that Cranmer's opinion was,‚Äî"That bi≈øhops and prie≈øts, were at one time, and were not two things, but one office, in the beginning of Chri≈øt's religion." Hi≈øt. Refor. Vol. I. collec. page 223. If they had one office, they had one and the ≈øame power: All therefore, that Cranmer intends is, that this work of ordination, which was originally common, had been, by the cu≈øtom of the church, appropriated to bi≈øhops. This interpretation makes Cranmer con≈øi≈øtent, whereas Mr. L's involves him in a plain contradiction.

HIS next extract is from bi≈øhop Jewel, in the≈øe words,‚Äî"We believe that there be divers degrees of mini≈øters in the church, whereof ≈øome be deacons, ≈øome prie≈øts, ≈øome bi≈øhops." That Jewel here only a≈ø≈øerts a matter of fact, or what were the officers then in the church, not a matter of right, or what ought to be by divine in≈øtitution, is evident from what he ≈øays in his apology. Speaking of the various degrees of the clergy in Jerom's time, he ≈øays,‚Äî"Chri≈øt appointed not the≈øe di≈øtinctions of orders from the beginning."‚Äî"This is the thing we defend, St. Jerom ≈øaith, let bi≈øhops under≈øtand, they are in authority over prie≈øts, more by cu≈øtom, than by order of God's truth. A prie≈øt is the ≈øame with a bi≈øhop; they are both one thing, and the churches were at fir≈øt, governed by the
common advice of prie≈øts." Apol. part. 2, c. 3. This plainly ≈øhews that in the pa≈ø≈øage quoted by Mr. L. he does not mean to declare his belief of the divine right of three orders; but only to a≈ø≈øert a matter of fact; and ≈øo is no proof that Jewel owned the divine right of epi≈øcopacy.

BUT Mr. L. ≈øuppo≈øes, this is proved to be the doctrine of the reformers, from the preface to the book of ordination. "It is evident to all men diligently reading the holy ≈øcriptures, &c.‚Äîthat there have been the≈øe three orders of mini≈øters," &c. Page 63. Upon which he ob≈øerves,‚Äî"It mu≈øt be evident to any man of common ≈øen≈øe, that the reformers, who compo≈øed this preface, believed the three offices of bi≈øhops, prie≈øts and deacons, to be of divine right, or none of them to be ≈øo; for they as po≈øitively a≈ø≈øert that all are, as that one is." An≈øwer:‚ÄîThey do not a≈ø≈øert that this one is. This preface only a≈ø≈øerts a matter of fact; that there had been ≈øuch orders from the apo≈øtles times. It does not declare that the≈øe three orders are of divine unalterable right:‚ÄîNor does it determine what kind of bi≈øhops were from the apo≈øtles times, whether dioce≈øan, or only parochial. And if Me≈ø≈ørs. Hoadly and Ollyffe, two epi≈øcopal divines, may be allowed to under≈øtand the ≈øen≈øe of this a≈ø≈øertion, as well as Mr. L. it will be nothing to his purpo≈øe. Mr. Ollyffe in his an≈øwer to Mr. Calamy, ≈øpeaking of this very preface, ≈øays,‚Äî"The propo≈øition of this rubrick is formed or expre≈ø≈øed, with as great a degree of latitude or moderation, as ever could be expected, from an epi≈øcopal church. It ≈øaith nothing of divine right or appointment. That is Mr. Calamy's addition, as Mr. Hoadly well ob≈øerves. It ≈øaith nothing of the di≈øtinction of their powers and officers; or whether they have been every where in every church or no: But only, that from the apo≈øtles times, there have been the≈øe orders,
&c.‚ÄîFrom which, the mo≈øt that can be inferred is, that in ≈øuch churches where there has been need of them, or occa≈øion for them all, there have been three ≈øuch ranks of mini≈øters, for the government and in≈øtruction of Chri≈øt's church, from the times of the apo≈øtles; which yet by Mr. Calamy's leave, does not prove a divine appointment of all, (however otherwi≈øe it may appear to him) there having been other things, in the apo≈øtles days, which yet, for all that, are not allowed to be of divine appointment." Here we ≈øee Mr. L's uncharitable interpretation of this preface, as though it meant to nullify all ordinations, ≈øave tho≈øe of the epi≈øcopal kind, ≈øtands expre≈ø≈øly condemned, by two celebrated divines of his own church. As their interpretation is more charitable and chri≈øtian-like, than Mr. L's; I pre≈øume every per≈øon of candor will judge it the true one; and con≈øequently, that his argument, founded on ≈øuch a ≈øtingy interpretation, can't be admitted as proof, that the venerable compilers of this preface, were of his contracted and ≈øchi≈ømatical principles.

THOUGH they here ≈øpeak of three orders in the church, yet they no where ≈øay, that bi≈øhops are by divine right, ≈øuperior to pre≈øbyters:‚ÄîNor is there the lea≈øt intimation, that they looked upon all ordinations to be null and void, unle≈øs performed by a bi≈øhop. For though they ≈øay "no man ≈øhall be accounted a lawful bi≈øhop, unle≈øs admitted according to the form there pre≈øcribed;" yet this is expre≈øily limitted "to that church of England." All therefore that can be meant by this, is no more than a declaration, who they will allow to be accounted lawful bi≈øhops of the national church of England: But this is no proof that they believed the divine right and ab≈øolute nece≈ø≈øity of dioce≈øan epi≈øcopacy, or accounted tho≈øe churches to have no valid mini≈øtry and ordinances, that are without it, as Mr. L. does. The contrary of this,
is undeniably evident from their practice, as I ≈øhall ≈øhew.

OUR author's la≈øt argument, to prove that the reformers were of his uncharitable ≈øentiments, in this point, is taken from the 3d, 7th, 8th, 9th, and 11th, canons of their church, which he has quoted at large. Page 63, 64, 65.

As the canons of the church of England, as they now ≈øtand, were compo≈øed at ≈øundry times; at periods far di≈øtant one from another; ≈øome in the reign of Queen Elizabeth, ≈øome in that of King James, &c.‚ÄîMr. L. ≈øhould have told us which cla≈øs, tho≈øe he has quoted belonged to: For if they were among the number of tho≈øe pa≈ø≈øed in King James's reign; they can't be ≈øaid to exhibit the ≈øentiments of the fir≈øt reformers, who had no hand in making them, being dead many years before. As he has not ≈øeen fit to do this, I might ju≈øtly forbear any further notice of them, as being nothing to the purpo≈øe of his argument.

HOWEVER, allowing they were of the fir≈øt cla≈øs, they will by no means prove, that the compilers of them believed the unalterable divine right of epi≈øcopacy, and denied the validity of pre≈øbyterian ordination. The ≈øub≈øtance of them is, (for they are too long to tran≈øcribe) "that if any per≈øon ≈øhould deny the church of England to be a true church, or declare her government by bi≈øhops, &c. to be anti-chri≈øtian, or repugnant to the word of God, or upon that account, or any other, ≈øeparate him≈øelf from her communion, he ≈øhall be ip≈øo facto excommunicated." But now there is nothing in the≈øe canons, that will prove the authors of them believed dioce≈øan epi≈øcopacy, to be of unalterable divine right. They might think it to be lawful, though not expre≈ø≈øly of divine in≈øtitution; much le≈øs that it was ab≈øolutely nece≈ø≈øary to the being of the church.

As to the charity of ≈øuch excommunicating, anathematizing canons, I mu≈øt leave it to the vindication of Mr. L. and tho≈øe of his ≈øtamp: For as to my≈øelf, I utterly de≈øpair of ≈øucceeding in any attempt of that kind. Americans, ble≈ø≈øed be God, have hitherto been unacquainted with ≈øuch damnatory canons. Their fulminations in this land, are heard, only like the di≈øtant thunders of the vatican. ‚ÄîHad not Mr. L's zeal for epi≈øcopacy, got the better of his prudence, I ≈øhould have judged he would have been more tender of the reputation of his be≈øt con≈øtituted church, than thus to expo≈øe her nakedne≈øs, by bringing to view the≈øe notable canons, in a country where they are ≈øo little known. Perhaps his de≈øign was to let us know what we are to expect, if the ≈øcheme for ≈øending bi≈øhops to America, erecting ≈øpiritual courts, &c. in the colonies, ≈øhould take place.‚ÄîBut to return:‚Äî

THE above remarks, I tru≈øt, make it ≈øufficiently clear, that it cannot be proved, either from the preface to the book of ordination, or from the canons, or indeed from any thing el≈øe Mr. L. has quoted, that the reformers were of his ≈øentiments, as to the divine right of epi≈øcopacy. They conformed to the epi≈øcopal church, as e≈øtabli≈øhed by the king and parliament, as what they tho't lawful, though not nece≈ø≈øary in it≈øelf, or of any ≈øcriptural or divine appointment.‚ÄîThat they did not look upon it as of divine in≈øtitution, is evident,‚Äî

1. FROM their expre≈øs declarations, both ≈øingly, and in a collective capacity. I have had occa≈øion already to cite ≈øome pa≈ø≈øages from bi≈øhops Cranmer and Jewel, in which they expre≈ø≈øly a≈ø≈øert it, as their judgment, "that bi≈øhop and pre≈øbyter, in ≈øcripture, is one and the ≈øame." The bi≈øhop of St. A≈øaph, Therlby, Redman and Cox, declared them≈øelves of the ≈øame opinion. Bi≈øhop Morton, in his catholic apology, declares, "that the power of order and juri≈ødiction, which the papi≈øts a≈øcribe

under≈øtand her con≈øtitution and principles, as well as the mi≈ø≈øionary of Norwalk?‚ÄîBut,‚Äî

3. THAT pre≈øbyterian ordination is valid, even in the ≈øen≈øe of the church of England, is evident, from the mo≈øt public and expre≈øs acts of the king and parliament. The church of England is properly a parliamentary church. She expre≈ø≈øly acknowledges the king as her head, inve≈øted with ≈øupreme power in all affairs, eccle≈øia≈øtical. AGAIN:‚ÄîThe ≈øame was done, A. D. 1707, by the act of union, whereby England and Scotland were united into one kingdom. HERE again we ≈øee, the ≈øupreme authority of the nation, king, lords, and commons, expre≈ø≈øly allowing the religion of the church of Scotland, and her pre≈øbyterian form of government, to be the true prote≈øtant religion. UPON the whole then, if any weight is to be laid upon the mo≈øt expre≈øs declarations of many great and learned men of the church of England, bi≈øhops as well as others, at the time of the reformation, and ≈øince, in their individual capacity, in favour of the validity of pre≈øbyterian ordination and government;‚Äîif any heed is to be given to the repeated in≈øtances, in which that church has, by her practice, owned and approved of that doctrine;‚Äî if any regard is to be had to public acts of parliament, acknowledging and declaring pre≈øbyterian churches and mini≈øters, to be true, lawful, prote≈øtant mini≈øters and churches; it mu≈øt be a mo≈øt clear and indubitable fact, that the church of England, neither at the time of the reformation, nor ≈øince, hath e≈øpou≈øed and maintained the doctrine of the divine right of epi≈øcopacy; but on the contrary does expre≈ø≈øly own the lawfulne≈øs and validity of pre≈øbyterian ordination and government. div.head: SEC. X. Animadver≈øions on Mr. L's appeal to the foreign prote≈øtants, concerning the validity of pre≈øbyterian ordination,‚Äî page 63, &c.
div.p:
IN this part of his work, our author pretends to give us ≈øundry extracts from the foreign prote≈øtants: Not indeed to prove, that the≈øe foreign churches are of the epi≈øcopal kind. This he knew was impo≈ø≈øible: But though they are pre≈øbyterians them≈øelves, yet that they do not allow our ordinations to be valid. Now, granting his quotations from Calvin, Beza, Le Mayne, &c. to be genuine; which, con≈øidering the freedom he u≈øes with other authors, is at lea≈øt very doubtful; they will by no means prove that the≈øe men denied the validity of ordination, even among the di≈ø≈øenters in England. What they ≈øeem to blame the old puritans for, is their ≈øeparating from the e≈øtabli≈øhed church of England, not for maintaining pre≈øbyterian principles. Be≈øides, it is well known what arts were u≈øed in them times, by the ≈øticklers for uniformity, to ≈øolicit the opinion of foreign prote≈øtants in their favour, and get them to di≈øcountenance the ≈øeparation. "About this time, ≈øeveral letters pa≈ø≈øed, between the Engli≈øh divines, on both ≈øides, and ≈øeveral learned foreigners.‚Äî Matters were fal≈øely repre≈øented to them, and great arts were u≈øed, on the bi≈øhops ≈øide, to prevent ≈øuch per≈øons writing, who they found would not write in their behalf; and what they thought made for them, they publi≈øhed to the world in way of triumph.
The foreigners were told, that unle≈øs they complied with the things enjoined, they mu≈øt let in the papi≈øts to ≈øupply the cures. Several foreigners therefore dreading that, and hoping the≈øe things would ≈øoon be altered, ≈øpake more favorable of them than they de≈øerved." Pierce's Vind. page 68. Moreover, the≈øe foreign divines knew, that epi≈øcopacy was ≈øettled in England, not as of divine right, but only by civil authority. Having this view of the Engli≈øh hierarchy, they might think it more advi≈øable for their brethren in England, to ≈øubmit to it, than to go into a ≈øeparation barely upon this account. For it is only on account of this, that they are, in Mr. L's quotations, ≈øuppo≈øed to ≈øeparate, and for which they are blamed. Whereas this was but one thing, among many, that cau≈øed the ≈øeparation. But what bu≈øine≈øs had Mr. L. with the di≈ø≈øenters of England? The pieces he attacks, undertook the defence of the New-England mini≈øtry, not that of the di≈ø≈øenters in England. There was no need of it. This has been repeatedly and ≈øucce≈øsfully done by many able writers of their own. Particularly by Me≈ø≈ørs. Baxter, Calamy, Pierce, and more lately the di≈ø≈øenting gentlemen in an≈øwer to Mr. White. Be≈øides, who does he mean by "the di≈ø≈øenters in this country?" If he intends New-England; bating a few anabapti≈øts and quakers, I know of no di≈ø≈øenters, ≈øave tho≈øe of his communion. Epi≈øcopacy never was e≈øtabli≈øhed here, though its oppo≈øite is, to the no ≈ømall mortification of our author and company. If therefore, the foreign divines had ≈øuch a regard to peace, as to advi≈øe their pre≈øbyterian brethren in England not to ≈øeparate, even from an epi≈øcopal church, by law e≈øtabli≈øhed: Who can ≈øuppo≈øe they would not condemn Mr. L. and party, in ≈øeparating from the e≈øtabli≈øhed pre≈øbyterian churches here, and becoming epi≈øcopal di≈ø≈øenters? Wherefore,
to come to the que≈øtion, as he has ≈øtated it; that is, "whether our ordinations in this country are allowed to be valid by the foreign prote≈øtants?" In an≈øwering of it I will pur≈øue his method, and "examine their public con≈øtitutions, their general practice, and their private ≈øentiments."

1. FROM the public con≈øtitutions of the foreign prote≈øtants, it is evident even to demon≈øtration, that they do and mu≈øt approve of our ordinations as valid. If they allow their own to be valid, they mu≈øt for this plain rea≈øon allow ours to be ≈øo; becau≈øe their con≈øtitutions, at lea≈øt ≈øo far as ordination is concerned, are preci≈øely the ≈øame with ours. Mr. L. I tru≈øt; need not be told that our ordinations are ≈øtrictly pre≈øbyterian, agreeable to our con≈øtitution: But the ≈øame is the con≈øtitution of the foreign churches. For the lutheran churches we have the concord of lutherans printed at Leip≈øick, containing the confe≈ø≈øion of Aug≈øburgh, and the apology for the ≈øame‚Äîthe Smalcaldic articles, Luther's greater and le≈ø≈øer catechi≈øm." From the≈øe authentic writings, we learn what the opinion of the Lutherans in this point is. And by the confe≈ø≈øion of all, even our adver≈øaries, 'tis manife≈øt that this power, is by divine right, common to all that are ≈øet over the churches, whether they be called pa≈øtors, or pre≈øbyters, or bi≈øhops.‚ÄîSince bi≈øhop and pa≈øtor are not different degrees by divine right, 'tis manife≈øt that ordination performed by a pa≈øtor in his own church is valid." Lib. con. tit. de pot. and juri≈ød. eccle. cited by Boy≈øe, page 282. The confe≈ø≈øion containing this

OF the ≈øame ≈øentiments in this point are the reformed churches comprehending the re≈øt of the foreign prote≈øtants. Helv. c. 18. This confe≈ø≈øion, as Mr. Boy≈øe ≈øays, was approved by the reformed churches of Scotland, France, Belgium or the Dutch, Poland, Hungary and many in Germany. Anc. Epi≈ø. p. 282. THE French prote≈øtant churches, in their confe≈ø≈øion pre≈øented to Charles IX. ≈øay,‚Äî"We believe all true pa≈øtors, wherever they are placed, to be endued with equal power, under that only head, the chief and univer≈øal bi≈øhop." Art. 30.

IN the Belgick or Dutch confe≈ø≈øion, we have the≈øe words, "In what place ≈øoever the mini≈øters of the word of God are, they have all the ≈øame and equal power and authority, as being all alike the mini≈øters of Chri≈øt, that only univer≈øal bi≈øhop and head of the church." The rea≈øon is, becau≈øe the principles of the papi≈øts, in this re≈øpect, are the ≈øame with theirs. But now, with an evidence beyond exception it appears, that all the foreign prote≈øtants are ≈øtrictly of our principles, as to the ordaining power; from whence it undeniably follows, that they mu≈øt allow and approve of our ordinations, as valid, becau≈øe they are the very ≈øame as are pointed out, in all their confe≈ø≈øions of faith.

2. THIS point is al≈øo evident from the univer≈øal practice of the foreign churches. All the Dutch churches throughout the united provinces, the prote≈øtant churches in France, tho≈øe of Geneva and the prote≈øtant cantons in Switzerland, &c.‚Äî are utter ≈øtrangers to bi≈øhops, both name and thing. And as to tho≈øe prote≈øtant churches which have officers they ≈øtile bi≈øhops, ≈øuperintendants or ≈øeniors; they are little more than ≈øtanding moderators, pretending to no ≈øuperiority, by divine right, over their brethren. "All the≈øe churches, ≈øays Dr. Stillingfleet, acknowledge no ≈øuch thing as the divine right of epi≈øcopacy, but ≈øtiffly maintain Jerom's opinion, of the primitive equality of all go≈øpel-mini≈øters." Iren. page 411. ‚ÄîNor can they do otherwi≈øe; having at bottom no other than pre≈øbyterian ordination among them: For Luther, Calvin, Bucer, Melancthon, Bugenhagius,
&c.‚Äîand the fir≈øt reformers and founders of the≈øe churches, who ordained mini≈øters among them, were them≈øelves pre≈øbyters and nothing el≈øe.

THIS again clearly proves, that they do in fact allow our ordinations to be valid; for they are the ≈øame with theirs. The Dutch churches therefore in Europe, beyond di≈øpute allow the validity of our ordinations. In America the ca≈øe is the ≈øame.‚Äî Here there are ≈øundry Dutch churches, originating from, and upon the ≈øame con≈øtitution, with the reformed prote≈øtant churches in Holland. The≈øe allow the validity of our ordinations. A number of years ago, a young gentleman of Dutch extract, came to New-Haven, and was ordained by our mini≈øters, at the College there, as a mini≈øter for the Dutch churches in the county of Albany.‚Äî This, as my author tells me, was done by order of the cla≈ø≈øis in Holland. The Rev. Mr. Woo≈øly, who was ordained by a number of Connecticut mini≈øters, over the church and congregation of Southold, on Long-I≈øland; after he left that people, and removed to his plantation, in Oy≈øter-Bay,
preached and admini≈øtered the ≈øacrament, in a Dutch church in that town, for twenty years together. The ≈øame did the Rev'd Mr. Ketteltas ≈øince.
